Many of us fear that things in Honduras will not change and that a very dangerous precedent will have been set, and the doctrine of the good, temporary, and not too cruel coup will have triumphed.

Mr President, I should like to congratulate the members of the Denby Committee and its chairman, Mr Lehne, for the work they have done to enable us to have a resolution such as the one we have and which we must approve without hesitation.
We can no longer be satisfied with merely talking about having enough sectoral agreements, because talking about a patchwork agreement is already admitting to a part of the failure.
We must go ahead and approve this Resolution, which has three noble aspirations.
A more obvious one is to avoid climate change with concrete proposals for reducing emissions and a commitment to funding, and to aim for a binding agreement, not piecemeal measures.

And two latent aspirations: one, to start working sooner rather than later on a common energy policy, just as we once established a common agricultural policy because it was necessary, and the other, of course, which is also included, to regain the citizens' trust in politics and in politicians, of which we do not have enough in Europe.
In that sense, the success of the summit will be the success of the three aspirations.
That is why I encourage the President-in-Office of the Council to continue with his optimism, to push and negotiate all he can to drag others into this success.

I don't know if the rulers of this multipolar world want to be judged by history for not being able to reach a binding agreement, but I, as a deputy, and I believe all representatives of the peoples, cannot be judged by history for not having been able, in Copenhagen, to achieve the binding commitment we have with humanity to avoid climate change.

Mr President, today there is no doubt about the European Union's commitment to the fight against terrorism and, thanks to the Stockholm Treaty, the Stockholm Programme, we will continue to make progress in this area of freedom, justice and security that is so necessary.

In my view, this struggle has been based on mutual trust between the member states, but it is high time, with the possibilities offered by the Treaty of Lisbon, to harmonize national legislations in the direction of not prescribing terrorist crimes, which should be considered crimes against humanity.

The day this happens, no one in this Parliament or any other will defend terrorists, as has happened, is happening, and may continue to happen, causing consequent harm to the victims of terrorism, who see those who murdered their loved ones being treated as heroes, while they suffer in silence.
I therefore ask this Parliament to promote or adopt the European Charter of the Rights of Victims of Terrorism, based on the defense of memory.
Mr President, I would firstly like to congratulate Mrs McGuinness on this initiative, which highlights the important role played by the CAP in meeting international food supply needs.

Now that the European Commission seems to want to reduce the weight of the CAP within the Community budget, it must be said very loudly and very clearly that the CAP is no longer a priority, but food sufficiency should be. In past decades, it has been seen that without the CAP, food sufficiency is very difficult, if not impossible, to achieve.
Agriculture cannot therefore be compared to other sectors of the economy that are able to thrive in a free market, because the food market is not a free market.

The farmer needs the support of the European Union to be able to run his business, and the Union, in turn, needs the farmer to maintain an agricultural model capable of providing sufficient and quality food to an increasingly demanding citizen.
I therefore believe that there should be a change of direction for the CAP, but it should not disappear.

To achieve this, it would be necessary to guarantee direct aid to farmers, in addition to reestablishing a policy of agricultural market management that provides greater price stability, which would benefit not only farmers, but also consumers and third countries.

It would be necessary to establish a framework of good practices to foster balanced relationships between the different agents in the food chain, avoiding abusive practices and promoting a fairer distribution of commercial margins.
In addition, a consumer information policy is needed for European consumers that emphasizes the efforts made by Community producers to comply with European Union regulations on:
environment, food safety and animal welfare, because Community producers have to compete with third country productions, where much lower standards are applied for imports.

And those producers from third countries prefer to export to the European Union rather than supply the markets in their own countries for a genuine matter of profitability, with the backing of WTO negotiations.
Mr President, according to a United Nations report, in 2009 around 270 people have been victims of human trafficking in the European Union.

With these figures in hand, it is necessary that the European Union's action is primarily based on the protection of victims, with special attention to the situation of women and children, who are the most vulnerable.
We cannot continue to stand by indifferently to this theater, to this spectacle of sexual exploitation that is unfolding before our eyes.
That is why I fully support this Parliament's request for assistance to victims to be unconditional, more decisive, and for harsher penalties, as Mr Barrot has just told us.
That being said, I would like to request that the Presidency and the Council use all the European legislation at their disposal, both existing and future, to protect victims of human trafficking.

I believe that the proposal for a European protection order for victims, which I personally requested from the Spanish Presidency during the debates on the Stockholm Programme and which has finally come to light, will be an effective instrument for combating these crimes.

And I expect a firm commitment, as we have already seen, from the Spanish Presidency to ensure that this order provides victims with special protection measures that are effective throughout the European Union.

I hope that those of us who have the responsibility to act on the most serious problems in our society will provide a real and concrete response to this extremely serious problem of human trafficking, and that we will not just stop at empty words.
We truly owe it to all the victims.
Mr President, Mr Zapatero, for a Spaniard, as I am, it is an honour to greet your presence here in your role as President-in-Office of the European Union.
There are many expectations and challenges in this period, and of course, we cannot fail to meet the expectations that have been created.
Let the public see that our renewed institutions are a tool capable of providing solutions to real problems.
But the report presented by your lordship knows that it is shared by us.
For the Popular Party of Spain, this is a matter of state, and we will support Your Excellency in everything that we see as common interests of Europe and that are important for Spain.
It is an ambitious program and one that, hopefully, will be filled with content.

I would like for people to be able to see in that album of the Spanish Presidency, since it will surely be colorful and varied, that they see in each event a milestone on real issues that affect them.
The crisis hits economies and unemployment seems like a fifth horse of the apocalypse.
You have had the honesty to acknowledge that 20% unemployment exists in Spain, but that does not incapacitate you.
What I believe is that it forces us all to produce a solution or problem, really, that we all have to solve together.
That is a real problem.
Time does not allow me to say much, Mr. President.

But I do want to tell you that Spain has many challenges ahead, and I believe, I am confident in Spain's capabilities as a nation, and I want to believe and I am sure that you will be up to the level of our country.

We cannot fail to meet these expectations at this hour for Europe. On the other hand, the globalized world, as you have so intelligently pointed out, is giving rise to new centers of power, and it is necessary for the European Union to play a more active and coherent role in defending its values and interests.
Otherwise, we run the risk of becoming irrelevant.
Finally, Mr. President, Spaniards do not accept that anyone denies us the ability to make proposals.
We have that legitimacy.
What we also need to have is the humility to accept those pieces of advice that Don Quixote received from Sancho when he recommended humility in his dream of governing the Island of Barataria.
I am pleased to say that José Luis Zapatero has not ceased to surprise European women with measures of great innovation and progress.
Of course, the formation of a truly equal government and the courageous way in which it has brought the issues of gender equality and respect for others to the European national agenda.
Mr President, I warmly congratulate you on your ambitious action programme, of course, against gender violence, which is a social scourge.
The creation of a European observatory on gender violence is a cutting-edge proposal that European women support and applaud.
Mr President, on behalf of the Portuguese socialists, I wish you good luck.
Can you count on our solidarity?
solidarity, women with shoes.
Mr. President, on a matter as serious as terrorism, we should not wait for events to take action.
We should anticipate this, but we don't.
And, unfortunately, we move forward through attacks like the failed attack in Troy, which today forces us to make decisions that guarantee the safety of air transport.
Deciding about body scanners at airports is a responsibility we cannot evade, ladies and gentlemen.
We cannot keep waiting, because terrorists do not wait.
Therefore, the Commission must assure us as soon as possible that the dignity and privacy of individuals will be preserved and that there will be no negative effects on health.
Having guaranteed this, we must adopt decisions for the entire European Union.

And to those who fear that fundamental rights will be violated, I say that there is no higher right than the right to live, and those of us who love freedom above all else need to live in safety in order to feel truly free.
Mr President, I believe that this crisis is an opportunity to move forward with determination and conviction in the creation of a strong Europe.

In that strong Europe, the expression "improve coordination" should probably be abandoned, as it makes everything dependent on the subjects to be coordinated and ultimately refers to paralysis and indefiniteness.
We know that the finances and public debts of European countries will suffer as long as there is no progress towards European financial integration and there are no Eurobond issues.

In any case, the European institutions can already take concrete actions—I won't insist on the rhetoric of coordination—and there are, on the one hand, the European Central Bank to harmonize financial supervision and
Mr President, I want to say that I have not come to this Parliament to applaud the newly enacted law on abortion in Spain.

What concerns me is human life and I am worried, above all, and I am here to defend women whose lives are in danger due to gender violence and to offer them a space in which they can live free and safe.

The Resolution of this Parliament, of February 2, 2006, recommends that the Member States adopt a zero tolerance attitude towards all forms of violence against women and that they adopt the necessary measures to ensure better protection for the victims.
The Stockholm Programme, approved in this Chamber, established an area of freedom, justice and security for all European citizens and considered the fight against gender violence a priority.

It reflected my request to the Spanish Presidency to promote a European protection order for victims of gender violence during its term, to ensure that victims of these crimes have the same level of protection in all Member States.

In a Europe without borders, the fight against gender violence should also have no borders, and the Member States should strive, when harmonizing their legislation, to ensure that the fight against mistreatment of women surpasses the

And therefore, I ask the Commission and the Council to do everything possible for the Commission and the Council to strive to ensure that the European Union's standards on women's and children's rights are respected.

everything necessary and everything within their power to ensure the success of this European protection order for victims, which is a very effective instrument for combating the impunity of those who do not respect women's dignity or their right to live free and safe.

It has been a long time since Fidel Castro and his oligarchy put an end to the ideals of the Cuban revolution that had such an impact and inspired so much hope among people all over the world, especially among the most brilliant international youth.
What characterizes, however, the dictatorship of the Castro brothers at this moment is the impiety towards political and prisoners of conscience, the impiety against their own people.
It reminds me of Franco the Moribund, with his mistreatment of political prisoners, whom he also considered common, his same obsessive contempt for the exiles.
Castro ends up like Franco and all the enemies of freedom when they become entrenched in power.
But we must save lives and show solidarity with those who are struggling and suffering.
It is our obligation as Europeans committed to democracy, freedom, and human rights.
Madam President, Mr. President of the Council, Commissioner, let us never again allow our silence to become complicity with those who destroy freedoms.

Let us never again allow a person who was fighting for their rights and those of everyone else to die in a Cuban prison or any other place without our raising our voice loud and clear demanding their salvation.

Mr. Orlando Zapata Tamayo, a 42-year-old citizen, a black construction worker, who only asked for improved prison conditions, died after 86 days of hunger strike and seven years in prison for demanding respect for human rights.
And during those seven years he was mistreated, humiliated, and reviled by his jailers, amidst, it must be remembered, a thick silence from the international community.
Other prisoners and human rights activists in Cuba are now on hunger strike, such as psychologist and journalist Guillermo Fariñas.

Ladies and gentlemen, the resolution that we are presenting today, debating today, and voting on tomorrow, and which I am representing on behalf of the Social Democrat Group, demands the release of all prisoners of conscience in Cuba.
It is once again pronounced in favor of a democratic transition and strict respect for fundamental human rights.
Let's not get into a topic that divides us at the moment, whether or not the common position should be maintained.
Let's focus on the topic now of saving lives and human rights.
And we are talking about a period of serene reflection in which we seek common ground on issues related to future policy with Cuba.
But this text also has an important added value.
The fact that six political groups are presenting it expresses a new era of broad consensus in this House on the issue of human rights.

Let it never again be claimed that the European democratic right bends to the orders of Yankee imperialism, but let it also never again be said that the social democrats are complacent or are accomplices to communist dictatorships.
Simply because both statements are false and the victims of the freedom killers, wherever they are, must know that they will find us united in the unconditional defense of their cause.
Mr President, I would finally like to thank Mr Salafranca, who negotiated this text on behalf of the European People's Party, Mrs Weber of the Alliance of Democrats and Liberals Group, and Mr
Mr Romévez, on behalf of the Greens, Mr Kasutnik, of the conservatives and reformers, and other colleagues who have participated in this difficult, complicated, but I hope successful effort tomorrow.

And, finally, I would also like to thank the President of the Spanish Government and President-in-Office of the European Union, Mr. José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero, for his encouragement and support in getting this Resolution that we are debating today off the ground.
"History will absolve me" was the famous plea of a young lawyer who moved his people to tears.
History, in fact, absolves him of his rebellion against tyranny and then against the American blockade.
But with the same emphatic judgment, this Parliament, which represents the greatest space of freedom and democracy in the world, condemns the dictatorship.
What is afflicting the people of Cuba? Is it the violation of human rights on the island? Is it the callousness towards political prisoners? Is it the contempt towards its exiled nationals?
The judgment of history is clear.
With this Resolution, deputies of all ideologies stand by the Cubans who are fighting.
Every possible means must be used to prevent the brutal repression they are suffering, even by going beyond the paralyzing so-called common position.
Tribute to the poet Raúl Rivero in the last verse of his Havana. Do not impose taxes on affection, emptiness, suffocation, bitterness.
The ruins of the homeland are safe.
Stay calm, comrades.
We're leaving now.
This week marked International Women's Day.
In this Parliament we had many posters in all the languages of the European Union saying that yes, violence against women can be ended.

Today we are talking about violence in Mexico and it seems normal to me to acknowledge that Mexican women, indigenous and non-indigenous, are the least protected victims by local and federal authorities.
Mexican women are victims of all forms of violence, from domestic violence to sexual violence and torture perpetrated by members of the army or police, and even homicide.
Unfortunately, so far, the responses from Mexican authorities have been ineffective, which is why it is correct to speak of almost absolute impunity.
Our Resolution calls on the Mexican Government to combat femicides - a harsh but accurate term when we see that almost all murders committed against women remain unpunished.
In the State of Mexico, in the last four years, only 11 of the criminals who murdered nearly 700 women were convicted.
At the same time, it seems that women are the preferred victims of the judicial system.
There is no other way to explain how it was possible that two indigenous women, Alberta Alcántara and Teresa González, were sentenced to twenty-one years in prison and even
Now, more than three years in prison for kidnapping and assault during an incident in a market, six men from the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
I hope the judge, who will decide in a week about the appeal in this case, realizes the ridiculousness and injustice of the situation. But violence against women starts in the family.

I hope that Mexican legislators will soon improve the General Law on Women's Access to a Life Free of Violence so that the types of violence and the mechanisms that make the norms cooperative are defined.
It would also be normal to establish that domestic violence and marital rape are criminal offenses.
Moreover, in order for Mexican society to change and reject violence against women, it is important that in schools this issue becomes a primary concern in the education of young people.
Madam President, the truth is that the first thing I would like to do this evening is to thank Mr. Scotty for his excellent willingness to negotiate this report.
It has been a real pleasure to work with him and with the other spokespersons of the parliamentary groups.

We are proud of the position that will be demonstrated in the vote tomorrow in this European Parliament and we are proud of a position like this that defends quality, that bets on the development and enhancement of rural areas, not only as a

Not as numerous witnesses of a traditional European culture, but as true agents generating wealth and employment, employment that we so desperately need now in these times of economic crisis and dramatic employment levels in some Member States.
We also appreciate the defence maintained by this European Parliament and the position it has already taken, as made clear by the Committee on Agriculture, to promote quality to the highest degree.
And, at that maximum level, we are, of course, committed to maintaining that differentiation between designations of origin and protected geographical indications.
Of course we reject the idea of lowering quality and we want attention to be paid to, and value to be placed on, community production.
I welcome Commissioner Cholo's words.
It seemed to me, of course, it was a pleasure to hear him talk about the commitment to the future of the European agricultural sector.
Of course, we hope that he will listen to the voice of this Parliament, which will be made clear tomorrow in that vote.

And finally, we hope that it will never happen again that the European Commission gets ahead of this Parliament by prohibiting things like, for example, marketing standards for fruits and vegetables, which have done so much damage to free competition in Europe.
We want market imbalances to be corrected and we also want to focus on quality, variety, food safety and an adequate quantity of production.
We also want community productions and the quality of these community agri-food productions to be defended in the World Trade Organization.
And for that, of course, we also have the work of Commissioner Cholos, because our European producers and consumers cannot continue to be defenseless.
Mr President, the Commissioner spoke about the absurdity and obsolescence of the procedures.
Let us, therefore, be consistent.
We have missed too many opportunities, too many treaties, to introduce Community competence over European airspace.
But if we could not intervene as we should in the sky, we did so in the skin of the earth
for example, by monitoring passenger rights and also mediating or calling for a truce in the various collective conflicts in land transport
No minimum services, maximum services to all parties.
Madam President, when coming from different and distant positions, such as those of Mauro, Kolnitz, or Kolmann, the conclusion is reached that there is none.
The procedure, the electoral systems, the election of Members of the European Parliament present problems, which means, Madam President, that we need a uniform electoral procedure.

which was a mandate that was already in the Rome Treaties and that is why the coordinators, and I want to take this opportunity to express my gratitude to everyone, but especially to Mr. Gaudí and Mr. Daf, have agreed on an amendment

Tomorrow, 2002, it will be voted on and I hope that this House will support it precisely so that this issue, this question of the uniform electoral procedure, assigned to the European Parliament, can be resolved soon.
I think that would eliminate this type of question.
In his speech, Mr Trzaskowski spoke about the necessary representativeness of this House, and this is a factor that most of the speakers, including Vice-President Šefčovič, have highlighted.
Of course, I agree and we say so in the report, in Article 1, that the eighteen enter en bloc, because if it were not so, we would lose representativeness.

And in order for them to join en masse, in order to fulfill that act of political justice that is the Lisbon Agreement, we must, ladies and gentlemen, be pragmatic, because a transitional and exceptional situation also requires transitional and exceptional solutions.

And that is why I do not hide the fact that I do not like the possibility of having deputies in this Chamber who have not come from the 2009 elections, I say this very clearly in paragraph 2, but if I have to choose between that and not having any...

If you turn 18 or are looking for a pragmatic solution and you turn 18, then we will comply with the Lisbon Agreement, and I ask this House, hence my report, to opt for that transitional, pragmatic, but above all, Madam President, fair solution.
Thank you very much to all for your collaboration and for the interesting contributions you have made to this work.

As I was unable to do so on March 11, International Day of the Victims of Terrorism, I would like today, from this Parliament, to pay them a well-deserved tribute that recognizes the enormous sacrifice of those who have paid the highest price in the name of freedom.

It is urgent to start working on a Directive that protects the rights of victims of terrorism, who are always the great forgotten ones and endure the humiliation of being unjustly equated with their executioners.
It is high time that these European institutions recognized the dignity of the victims of terrorism and helped them in their right to protection and justice, which should soon be translated into law.

that will honor all those who make it possible and that the first article, that support for the victims of terrorism is recognized as the right to justice and that no government will ever pay a political price.

I appeal to all those who can defend the victims to never forget that true peace is born from justice, and that is the only one that we who believe in it must defend from Europe and from anywhere in the world.

Mr President, it has been necessary, Mr President, to face the abyss and the economic collapse for the heads of state and government to understand that the path forward is not one of more nationalism, but of more Europe.
Measures such as the decline of the veto right in the European Council or the seed of a European public treasure are circulating in this direction.
Finally, albeit belatedly, we have realized that we are all in the same boat and that it is futile to address individual situations, especially in an improvised manner.

But I wonder if this attitude is a parenthesis or, on the contrary, the beginning of a true European economic government, because what is in excess, dear colleagues, is governance and what is lacking is authentic government if we want to be faithful to the testament of the founding fathers.

That is why, from this Parliament, we must push for all those reforms that aim to strengthen Europe and make budgetary and fiscal discipline a reality, forgetting, of course, about nostalgic sovereignties.

Ladies and gentlemen, colleagues, strengthening the European Commission and strengthening this Parliament is the only correct recipe for building a Europe that would otherwise vanish like a fleeting shadow.
Mr President, Commissioner, on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, I would like to thank Mrs de Sarney for the cooperation we have received.
Today, more than ever, the Union for the Mediterranean, the strengthening of major projects, and institutional development are necessary.
Today, more than ever, it is necessary to find solutions to the exit from the crisis, to research, to climate change, to water, to new energy models, to sustainable development.

And to achieve this, it is necessary to promote and finalize commercial and economic relations in the area with short-term and long-term measures: free trade zone, elimination of tariff barriers, opening of the North-South and South-South markets.
The Barcelona Summit, the Spanish Presidency, will provide the opportunity for a new commitment, a new situation, a new sharing of ideas, the democratization of economic and social solutions.
The Barcelona Summit can put us in a position to lead the Mediterranean.
Madam President, within the trans-European transport corridors is the railway corridor known as the Mediterranean corridor.
It is a vital communication that will connect North Africa with Europe.
For Spain, it is vital because this axis is a priority, as it would connect Algeciras with Europe.
Not being excluded from other priority routes, it would pass through Almería, Murcia, the Valencian Community and Catalonia.
And why has Commissioner Reding said this? She said there is greater economic activity and a high concentration of land transport.
This is one of the two conditions.
The possibility of communicating with various ports in the Mediterranean area was opened up.
We need to gain economic momentum and be competitive, as the Commissioner also said, because this region produces more than 50% of Spanish exports.
Therefore, if we increase the topic of a strategic railway axis through the Mediterranean, we will increase greater competitiveness for Spain and greater competitiveness for Europe.
Madam President, I would like to take this minute to congratulate the Spanish rotating Presidency for the efforts it has made this semester to overcome the crisis.
a common position with regard to Cuba and create a new type of relationship between the European Union and Cuba that includes, naturally and as a priority, the defense of human rights.
That policy has not been crowned with success, basically due to the intransigence of the Cuban dictatorship that began this presidency, precisely in January.
This year, with the expulsion of the deputy speaking to you, when he was trying to visit, with all the visas and all the legality, the island to concern himself with the human rights of the island.
But that policy, that new policy that the Spanish government undertook, will yield its results sooner rather than later.

Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues, this is a regulation that is of paramount importance for consumers and for the agri-food industry, because it is not easy at all to achieve balanced labelling that contains all the essentials, but is not so exhaustive that it complicates the information.
This is a great report and the rapporteur should be congratulated on it.
I agree with her on the major issues relating to nutritional information and the controversial issue of profiles, especially considering that the Commission did not comply with
the commitment to establish these profiles, as well as their conditions of use, before January 19, 2009, as prescribed by Regulation No. 1924

There is one issue that concerns me, and that is the possibility of national rules on labelling being inconsistent, because this goes against the objective of the legislation, which is harmonisation and avoiding all possible obstacles to the functioning of a genuine single market.
Regarding the indication of the country of origin, current legislation stipulates that this information must be provided when, in the event that it is not indicated, it could mislead the consumer.
In addition, voluntary labeling is always expected to be available.
But going further can involve economic costs and administrative complexity for companies, without providing any significant benefit, of course, to the consumer.
And, regarding the use of different languages, I must say that the Commission's proposal is in line with the existing Directive, which has worked well and has not caused any problems.
And reopening this debate can be dangerous and necessary and cause problems for the circulation of products.
Mr. President, the best proof of our good will is the thousand amendments we are seeing from the Commission to the plenary.

But, in addition to good intentions, I believe we must be practical when it comes to labeling food if we do not want to achieve the opposite effect of what we are pursuing, that is, to confuse the consumer instead of helping them to become informed.
It is not about illustrating, but about preventing, about informing what you can eat and to what extent.
measure must be labeled on fats on sugars on trans fats
Well, indeed
We are indeed talking about those things that affect cholesterol, all those substances that affect what we have said, obesity, and people's health.

Yes, but some other foods, with some other information, such as the place of origin, when it does not lead to confusion, or, for example, in a piece of meat, saying the place of birth, the place of transit, the place of grazing, the place of sacrifice of the cows, can be very illustrative, but they will end up causing confusion.

It is up to us to be practical and ensure that this Regulation is the one that will harmonize and inform consumers, or, if not, the one that will cause more confusion and impose issues that, far from achieving better health accounts, will result in greater degrees of confusion.

That's why I ask, for example, that some opt for the GDA, the daily intake amount, instead of the traffic lights, because it's very clear that if you consume this amount or double it, you'll get fat, so consume only one.
Some people suggest the amount of daily intake versus all types of codes, so as not to confuse the consumer further.
Madam President, many thanks, Mr Martín Fraguero, for being here, on behalf of the Spanish Presidency, for a report like this, Commissioner for Foreign Affairs.
Mr. Milana, congratulations on your ability to reach a common agreement and reconcile all interests, and to present an own-initiative report, one of the first own-initiative reports.
The development of aquaculture is important.

It is necessary due to the increase in fish consumption and the stagnation of fishing extraction capacity, but I want to emphasize at this moment the economic importance of this activity, which generates economic wealth and creates jobs.
Health guarantees are important, sustainability is important, and the protection of the marine environment is important.
The image of aquaculture must be enhanced, and the scientific and research sector must also be strengthened.
Aquaculture is an opportunity, as Mr. Martin Frareiro said within the CFP, as the Commissioner said.

We need to give it a coherent framework for coordination, we need to give it the possibility to regularize itself, because aquaculture can mean sufficiency, sustainability and economic resources, and I think it is important for Europe.

Mr President, in my opinion, this excellent report outlines the guiding principles that should inspire the new Transport White Paper, which will shape European transport policy for the next ten years.

The present report highlights several key points that underscore the need for a financial fund as an essential tool, the challenge of the increasing demand for freight transport, and the search for multimodal solutions that
the urgent need for sufficient and safe rest areas in road transport, the diagnosis, in my opinion accurate, that there should not be mere competition between the different sectors.

In other words, they should not be in competition, but rather complement each other by seeking criteria of efficiency. The speaker's assertion, which I consider to be both courageous and fair, is that rail or maritime transport is not always more environmentally friendly than road transport.
In short, the concept of an efficient community is a future concept and, in my opinion, it must undoubtedly be supported with all rigor.
Is it a mistake in approach, Mr. President?
Did you think you were really going to preside over Europe and influence the gears that make the complex European machinery run?
He even came to believe, because people close to you let him proclaim it, that the world would experience a stellar moment under his presidency.
None of this has come to fruition.
Let us clarify a few points.

In these six months of the Spanish Presidency, I would like to distinguish, on the one hand, between the political direction of the Presidency and, on the other, the work of the officials who have been working in the engine rooms.
The first one has failed, and this is due to the absence of adequate impetus from the Presidency of the Government, which has been more of a back-and-forth affair.
However, I want to highlight the effort of the officials, their valuable willingness to serve Europe and Spain.
And the fact is, Mr. President, Spain has magnificent professional civil servants, and if there is anything to be lamented, it is that they are too often marginalized in daily reality.
That being said, it should be acknowledged that some commendable initiatives have been adopted in these six months.
Among them, I am pleased to mention the organ donation and transplantation plan and the treatment given to patients' rights in cross-border healthcare.
The agreements on the new 2020 Strategy and, above all, those concerning the European External Action Service, have remained more in the air, both still being too fragile.
What has happened with the European protection order for victims of gender violence has been lamentable, and the same dismal result has been offered by the
A Community patent, essential for the survival of thousands of companies and partially blocked by the linguistic problems that Spanish legislation encourages.

But all the major political actions have ended in spectacular failure. From the Mediterranean summit to the European Union summit with the United States, the latter of which was characterized by the fact that his own government was responsible for creating excessive expectations.
However, we must agree that the inability to implement its policy regarding Cuba has been highly positive for Cubans.
Finally, the progress made towards better European economic governance cannot in any way be attributed to his Presidency, which was conspicuously absent from the most relevant issues.
Farewell, then, to the Spanish Presidency.

I do want to draw one positive conclusion from this experience: my fantasy as a convinced Europeanist is excited at the thought of what this could mean for the end of rotating presidencies, as they have been conceived up to now.

This would be good news, because as long as Europe does not strengthen its common institutions, solidly uniting its fragments, it will continue to run the risk of being submerged in the void of irrelevance.
Mr President, believe me, Mr Zapatero, I would have liked to have delivered a different speech today.
You, Your Lordship, set up a semester full of ambition and set the bar so high in your aspirations that, when comparing it to what was actually achieved, disappointment is inevitable.
The fact is that your Lordship has not been able to overcome a complex situation, which required leadership and credibility.
Your Lordship has once remarked that the European Union is a club with rules, and I agree.
But it was His Lordship who was responsible for enforcing those rules.
The reality is that it was the Government of Spain to whom they were urgently demanding the fulfillment of its obligations.
In this picture, positive achievements that have not been lacking have been overshadowed.
Your Lordship has had time to recount them, I have not.
Democracy, ladies and gentlemen, is a regime of public opinion.
And that is what Obama's disdain, the cancellation of the Mediterranean Summit, and the announced European Union to the United States appear to be: deeply rooted failures.
The rush to close improvised agreements at any cost has not enhanced the image of Spanish management, as Chapucero has been described as a way to achieve any respectable goal.
Spain is a great nation and will continue to be so, despite the mismanagement of this time.
Our diplomats and officials have maintained their composure and, thanks to this, Spain's prestige will continue.
The truth is that the judgment of this Presidency will be more influenced by the situation in Spain than by what has or has not been done here.
It was hardly possible for someone who has placed their country in a state of uncertainty and unease to lead such a difficult company.
Well, at best, this presidency has been sadly irrelevant.
Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in the coming months we will fully enter into the debate on the new CAP.

It is important to reach a good agreement, so I hope that the Belgian Presidency will achieve what the Spanish Presidency has not managed to do, namely to steer the discussions in such a way that the Member States commit to maintaining a policy in the future.

A truly strong common agricultural policy, with a sufficient budget to meet the needs of the twenty-seven Member States, both new and old, so that what happened in 2005 does not recur, when there was a lack of money and modulation had to be invented.

The next reform of the CAP will determine the viability of a sector that not only provides intangible goods and services, such as environmental care, but should also ensure the supply of food to European citizens.

We have already witnessed painful situations of scarcity in the past, so it is necessary for the European Parliament to ensure security and supply based on community production as the main objective of the next reform, without neglecting other contributions such as the fight against climate change.

Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, I agree with Commissioner Cholos that this report is necessary, very necessary, and it comes at a good time, because it has demonstrated the abuses committed by large-scale distribution by severely disrupting the various links in the food chain.

The Bové report, which at some point may go too far in trying to be too interventionist, must be recognized from the perspective of a social market economy, such as the one advocated by the European People's Party, which incorporates responses to the legitimate demands of European producers.

Moreover, it brings transparency to the different parts of the food chain, which is always a good thing, and gives much more scope and support for the weaker sectors of that chain to defend themselves, and of course supports European consumers in learning more about that chain.

Madam President, the European food industry could have been given more consideration in this report, and perhaps it would have been very good, but this report also includes measures to curb price volatility, and that was very necessary.

Measures are also included to ensure fairness for these links in the chain, as requested by the Committee on the Environment, and there is also a call to combat the abusive and unfair practices of large-scale distribution.
And it is high time to establish a list of abusive practices and for European legislation to strictly prohibit them.
It is also important that measures are taken to prevent unfair practices through white labeling, which are against competition and violate the Intellectual Property Law.

For all these reasons, we must support the Bové report and support all our colleagues who, from the various parliamentary committees INCO, ENVI or Agriculture, have shown that they are working hard to ensure that this report finally comes to light and helps European producers to get back on their feet.
the alarm bell rings and it's true
And there is also frustration, as can be heard in the speeches in this plenary session, for not having achieved the millennium goals.
And the truth is that what is at stake is very much.

Our natural environment is so fragile that if one day the big fish decided not to continue eating the small fish, we would have to pay for everything out of our generational pocket, with our health and well-being as the currency of exchange.
The European Union is a leader today in the fight against climate change and has been for some time in pioneering conservation measures.

But as the unmet targets demonstrate, it seems as though there has been a lack of will, not only for implementation and coordination that have also been mentioned here, but also for expansion beyond our very limited special conservation zones.
Of course, biodiversity is not a museum piece that can be locked away in a ghetto area, as sometimes seems to be done, with a glance from time to time.
Biodiversity is alive and knows no borders; it crosses the entire earth with a domino effect in which, if one piece falls, all the others fall.

I draw attention to the need for a global and more community-based approach, especially with regard to soil, because subsidiarity, as the sole method for managing soil or forests, can be one of the new formidable enemies of biodiversity.

That is why I draw attention to paragraph 67 and the possible vote that will be cast, and I ask you to reject the second part, because I am convinced that a common policy on soil would help to conserve the entire territory.

A European world so varied, so diverse for better or for worse, and so lacking in political will on the part of the states, and so in need of more and more European Union, in the fullest sense of the word, which means more union also for the land.

Mr President, Commissioner, first of all I want to highlight the work of the rapporteur, Mrs McAvan, not only in terms of content, but also in terms of form, because she has done it in collaboration with all the shadow rapporteurs.
We would also like to thank the experts from the Spanish Administration for their contribution to this agreement.

The purpose of this European Union pharmacovigilance system is to strengthen the surveillance, transparency, and communication of the safety of food and marketed medicines, especially with regard to their risk profiles and the adverse reactions they may produce.

It is worth noting the creation of the European Pharmacovigilance Committee, which will evaluate and issue recommendations to the European Medicines Agency regarding safety issues that may arise with medicines marketed in the European Union.

The solution reached for the ultra-vigilance notification of suspected adverse reactions to medicinal products is very important, both for the Member States and for the marketing authorisation holders.

Ultra-vigilance will be the only source of information, but at the same time, the competent authority of the Member State where the adverse reaction is suspected to have occurred will be informed, and this is very important.
It is also worth noting the opportunity it provides consumers to report any adverse reactions, and in this regard, the Agency's creation and management of a portal.

The European Medicines Agency's portal on medicine safety, which in turn links to the portals of each member state, will help improve citizens' knowledge about the safety of the medicines they consume.
And, finally, we cannot forget that, since pharmacovigilance plays a fundamental role in protecting public health, the approval of the Directive and the
This Directive and this Regulation will contribute significantly to this, by improving not only the current procedures, but also the coordination of actions between the different Member States.

Mr President, I greatly appreciate the rapporteur's efforts to accept some suggestions and, of course, her defence of copyright, which I share, but the inclusion of the infringing and punishable nature of certain exchanges and the

The recognition of sanctioning authority to suppliers, as well as the alternative resolution excluding mass exchanges as a possible violation, make it impossible to vote in favor of either of the two reports in Liza.
The Gallo report has aroused great interest and could have been timely, but the core of the debate is too heatedly centered around the argument for or against the French law called
Pi, a disconnection from the Internet for offenders, without there having been a genuine European debate that takes into account the reality of other progress in national legislation.

I hope that we will reach a common position within the Socialist Group and a majority in the European Parliament in the debates and amendments on the Commission's proposed Directive, which will soon be submitted to Parliament, as announced by Commissioner Barnier.
On that occasion, we will try to reach a more balanced position than today, one that takes into account both the rights of Internet users and the essential respect for intellectual property.
Mr President, I congratulate those who have worked on this report, on this financial package, especially the officials and the Members of this Parliament.
A financial crisis of enormous proportions had to occur for Europe to wake up.
However, an opportunity has been missed, in part, to strengthen Europe's common institutions, because, on the one hand, these new supervisory authorities have a scope of competence.
limited compared to similar authorities in Member States and it is also regrettable that no progress has been made towards a similar integration to that which occurred with the central bank system.
We have made progress, but we must continue to climb the mountain.

Madam President, as a member of the Human Rights Committee, as a Spanish and European citizen, and as a victim of terrorism since the ETA terrorist organization murdered my brother and his wife in Seville, I am addressing this Parliament to denounce the Government of Venezuela and its president for allowing terrorists from

The ballots are trained in their Venezuelan stronghold under the orders of the alleged terrorist Cubilla, who works for the government of Hugo Chávez, despite an international arrest warrant being in effect against him, which is a serious violation of the fundamental right to security of any European citizen.
I demand that the Government of Spain take decisive action in the face of this grave humiliation of all Spaniards.
Zapatero cannot remain silent while the Venezuelan ambassador calls our civil guards torturers, who have been and will be an example of bravery in the fight against ETA.
Nor can we turn a blind eye to the growing cooperation between ETA and the FARC on Venezuelan soil, as Judge Eloy Velasco has already denounced.
Zapatero cannot shake hands with a leader like Chávez, who is turning Venezuela into a haven for terrorists.

The president of a country like Spain, where terrorism has caused so much pain, cannot continue to ignore this problem and should give it the response it deserves and that any ordinary citizen would give if they had the opportunity to do so.
Mr President, on 14 February 2008, as a Valentine's Day present, the Conference of Presidents decided that the intergroups would only meet on Thursdays.
Since then we have been trying to resolve this issue.
We haven't managed to do it.
The intergroups today, Mr. President, have to meet on a date that is not suitable.
They almost never have rooms and they never have interpretation.

Today I speak not only as president of the Poverty and Human Rights Intergroup, but with the mandate of most of the Intergroups in this House, and therefore of the members of this House who are part of those Intergroups.
And I solemnly request that the Conference of Presidents reconsider and annul the Decision of February 14, 2008, and return to the previous situation of freedom for the intergroups.
And if it does not, I also say politely that we will bring the matter to the plenary of this House and it will decide who in this House is sovereign, which is this Parliament.
Mr. President, the International Day against Human Trafficking and Exploitation brought to light some data that should prompt us to act immediately.
More than 90% of prostitution in Europe is a result of blackmail and extortion.

And, in light of these facts, we should ask ourselves whether we are doing everything necessary to protect the dignity and integrity of thousands of women whose rights are also protected by the Fundamental Charter that we adopted with the Treaty of Lisbon.
Because we are not talking about the oldest profession in the world, but about the only form of slavery that we have not managed to eradicate from old Europe.
Countries such as Spain are making significant efforts in this regard by pursuing traffickers, raising public awareness, and promoting reintegration plans for female victims.
But it is not enough.
Europe must be a single space of action and commitment.

The next Directive on Combating is an opportunity to address the demand through education and make it more difficult to access, for example, by offering advertising opportunities in all types of media, in addition to increasing bilateral cooperation with third countries to combat this scourge at its source.
We have an opportunity
This Parliament draws attention to itself for continuing to be at the forefront of citizens' rights.
Madam President, we all agree that the foreign service is a historic opportunity for European construction.

But to achieve this, it is necessary to act with a broad vision, because now is not the time for internal struggles over resources that are transferred or retained in the short term, or for wars between the different European institutions.
What is needed now, on the contrary, is to have an overall vision of what the European Union should be in the world, that is, to do just the opposite of
And that is what happened a few days ago, on the occasion of the awarding of the Nobel Peace Prize, where too many voices were heard from Europe, and not all of them were brave.
One of the exceptions to note is the President of this Parliament, Mr. Buzek, who is the author of a brilliant and dignified statement.

Mr. President, the regulation we are debating today is of vital importance for the future of an industry, that of cutlery and related products, which in my region, the land of Don Quixote, specifically in Albacete, represents not only the survival of more than eight thousand jobs, but also an element of identity and a commitment to the future of craftsmanship as a source of employment.
And the Meidín seal for knives has long been advocated by social groups such as Precu and fought for by the Government of Castilla la Mancha with the unanimous support of its regional Parliament.
A seal of origin that is not interventionism is a commitment to transparency in the rules of trade and the fight against fair competition.

It is to increase consumers' decision-making capacity when choosing a product so that they take into account not only the final price of the product, but also the quality brand, the place of origin, or the social conditions under which it is produced.

And, above all, it will represent a new horizon of optimism for many people who are going through a tough time, but who are looking at us today thinking that we have not been indifferent when it comes to advocating for fairer trade, yes, but also for adding value to those who, in addition to producing, do so with respect for social rights and the best conditions for European workers.
That is why I am grateful to the speaker and Mr. Menéndez del Valle for their political support and social awareness on this important issue for my region.
Mr. President, let's see if I can bring a bit of calm to this lively debate.
It is regrettable that some countries and some of the states that make up the European Union are still present at this G20 forum.
Despite this anomaly, which certainly weakens Europe's image in the world, it would be good if there were at least a common global position in that world forum.
And what would, in my opinion, be that common position?

In my humble opinion, I believe that, firstly, the adoption of a comprehensive agreement to address the consequences of the crisis cannot be delayed, and not just a financial agreement. Secondly, Europe must maintain the euro as a reference currency or, if preferred, as an anchor for

In order to prevent the turbulence in the markets from dragging us along and making us repeat the mistakes that were made throughout the 20th century, the euro, in the third place, must serve as a herald of what Europe should represent in the world of democratic values and freedoms.
public.
In summary, it is important to know that in the global world, in this global game, those who only play national cards lose.
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that we are in a position to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Meissner.
I think that different positions were found and she has obtained compromise solutions that allow us all to be together on an important issue.

Ladies and gentlemen, the Transport Committee has decided that all seas should be protected in a similar manner, and to this end, it argues that if this were not the case, a situation of unfair competition would arise.

We accept the majority position in favor of a legal situation with uniform rules for the entire Union, but I will not spare this House from pointing out clearly that it also implies a certain lack of fairness.
It is evident that the Baltic Sea, the North Sea and the English Channel are more polluted areas and that controls on sulphur limit values will have to be more stringent in these cases.
The measures concerning ports should be positively evaluated, as they affect solutions to reduce transportation times and handling costs.
In any case, I will not tire of reiterating that we still have work to do on this issue.
If a decisive liberalization of ports is not undertaken, they will not be able to expand the central role they are meant to play in the context of convenience.
Welcome also, Ladies and Gentlemen, the impetus of a strategy aimed at modifying the specific impacts of climate change.
I believe this is a positive report, one that we should vote for.
But we must not forget that it occurs in the context of a major disaster, that of the Gulf of Mexico.

And, in this regard, the Commission is urged to assess whether the framework of the review of the Regulation of the European Maritime Safety Agency strengthens the role that the Agency should play in the prevention inspections and subsequent tasks of cleaning up oil spills.
My personal view, Commissioner, is that yes, and that these tasks should be reinforced with the mandate that is required for this purpose.
Mr President, the integrated maritime policy is a cross-cutting, regional and sectoral policy, which must include fisheries policy and aquaculture, and it must not be subordinated to other policies.
We must all respond to environmental and economic problems, both to society in general and to the fishing industry. New technologies, fishing gear, species development, a plan for maritime economy...

to create more and better jobs, quality supplies, international relations that prevent piracy, and promote the governance of our seas, which have no barriers and do not have sustainability problems, as in the case of Iceland.
This would be working towards an integrated maritime policy, this would be working towards the environment and sustainability.
Madam President, the Church of Our Lady of Help was recently attacked in Baghdad, and 58 people, mostly women and children, were murdered simply because they were Christians.
Al Qaeda has proudly claimed authorship of the feat.
It is not an isolated incident, but the culmination of persecutions and attacks on Christians in countries with a Muslim majority.
Expulsions in Morocco, threats in Turkey, attacks in India or Nigeria.
In January, six Christians were massacred at the door of a church in Cairo.
Cairo: How long will the complicit silence of Western democracies last?
Fortunately, President Buzek has made an institutional statement.
High Representative Lady Ashton's statement of condemnation was limited to a condemnation of a terrorist act.
Why is the motive not mentioned? The fact that they were Christians, which is the unequivocal cause of the massacre.
I haven't heard anything from Mr. Zapatero, I haven't heard anything from President Erdogan.
And, Erdogan, what is the purpose of the Alliance of Civilizations?
I feel sorry for our foolishness and our cowardice.

Inevitably, the memory comes to me of the lamented and misunderstood Oriana Fallaci, who announced the arrival of Eurabia and was almost stoned for having the courage to denounce what is happening in complex Europe.
Also to the Commissioner. I share the desire of this House.
I want the proposals from the Europeans to get the support they deserve in Cancún.
In relation to this debate, it is important to emphasize the role of cities in environmental preservation.

There is an agreement between more than a thousand mayors of the European Union that demonstrates the existence of recognition of the problem by these authorities, whose actions are crucial if we want to succeed.
The grand words we use are of no use if we do not have the cooperation of the mayors of the cities.
It is therefore very important that emissions are disclosed, as cities produce almost 80% of greenhouse gases.
Today, there is no such disclosure, and, worse still, there is no common standard for measuring these emissions themselves.
There is a non-profit organization called the CO2 Disclosure Project that already hosts information from thousands of companies and which, I think, could also be used by municipalities.
Without their cooperation, without the cooperation of these municipalities and mayors, environmental action remains nothing but smoke, the very smoke we want to escape from.

Mr. President, some have said that the condemnation of Morocco is too lenient given the magnitude of the repression of human rights in the Sahara, where Morocco is nothing more than an occupying country without sovereignty or any legal title.
But the important thing is the message that all of Europe and this Parliament can no longer tolerate his violence.
Yesterday I spoke about the Hague Tribunal in this very Parliament.

The international community, which sadly failed to prevent genocide in Rwanda, Yugoslavia, and Darfur, I hope will prevent that of Western Sahara, and that we will not have to see it before another court, also in The Hague, as I mentioned, but this time for war crimes.
Mr President, Commissioner, the Directive adopted in 2009 was a success because it updates the regulatory framework that has been governing safety in toys.
It is a big step in the right direction, because it shows us the way forward, but it is not enough.
We must always be vigilant and attentive to ensure that the toys being marketed do not endanger the safety and health of children.
All toys on the market must comply with current legislation.
We must review and improve the surveillance mechanisms to detect dangerous toys, whether due to substances considered toxic, fragrances, and other hazardous substances, such as HPA compounds.
The rules to be followed need to be clearer about the warning regarding the minimum age and the dangers resulting from improper use.
The recommended age for toys must be based on studies of children's behavior.
We need to be able to adapt our regulations to scientific advances supported by solid studies and be more rigorous in market surveillance and the importation of toys.
It is necessary to work together and strengthen cooperation between member states and rely on the joint work of customs to control the route of imported toys.
Citizens are getting ready to do their holiday shopping, and we must give them the assurance that the products they buy meet all safety requirements.
In this debate, it has become clear that we all agree to support the objective of this report.
The different political groups have shown their support for this Directive, which offers greater protection to victims.
Therefore, I wonder what obstacle there is to approving this instrument.
I repeat: What fears are there that something so necessary and simple as protecting victims equally throughout Europe will finally become a reality?
Hoping that this Parliament will approve this report by a majority, I address the Council and the Commission, reminding them that we have
We have overcome the legal hurdles in our negotiations and I applaud the Commission for recognizing our work, just as we recognize the work it will do in the future.

So we do not need to exclude ourselves, but rather to help each other, by approving this more concrete instrument today and the broader package of measures to aid the victims that the Commission will present tomorrow, and with which I commit to collaborating.
Therefore, let us be brave and responsible today and help all those who have the right to live in a safer Europe.
Let's help everyone, I repeat, whether they are men, women or children.
Let us help those who are looking to us today for a better life, a life that will return to them their freedom, their security, and, above all, their dignity.

Madam President, the Group of the European People's Party will vote enthusiastically in favour of this report, and I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteurs, the Commission and the Council on this agreement.
We coined, ladies and gentlemen, in the eighties, the term democratic deficit.
With this, we meant that in the European Union, decisions were made only by the Council of Ministers on proposals from the Commission, and this Parliament was only consulted.
The battle of this Parliament since the 1980s, through the Maastricht Treaty, the Amsterdam Treaty, the Nice Treaty, the Constitutional Treaty, the Lisbon Treaty, has been

fill that democratic deficit. And I believe that with the Treaty of Lisbon, with the new powers of the European Parliament, with the participation of national parliaments, we have achieved that objective.
And we rounded it off today with this citizens' legislative initiative, which was due, in the work of the Convention, to the good cooperation between national Parliaments and the European Parliament.

And I want to remember here the names of Jürgen Meyer, our German Social Democrat colleague, and Annan Lamassoure, who were the ones who brought that initiative to the penultimate Convention and who made it approved.
Therefore, I believe we have come full circle, Madam President.
I believe that today, when we vote on the initiative, we will have drawn up, put on the table, the death certificate of the concept of democratic decision-making.
It is now up to us, ladies and gentlemen, to act responsibly, and today we also have the opportunity to do so.
By voting on the Union's budget, we will fulfill what is expected of us as a responsible Parliament and a Parliament with codecision powers.
I believe it is a good day for Europe, ladies and gentlemen.
Mr. President, in January 2012, 400 Spanish egg producers could disappear, around 30% of the total in my country, with the loss of 300 tons of egg production.

And the European Union could stop producing those 80 million eggs, those 2 million tons, and we would only manage to have them covered by imports from third countries, whose animal welfare standards are much lower than those of the European Union, if we do not act with great intelligence.
This 1999 Directive, which requires an increase in the space of laying hen cages, demands that we act intelligently and with a positive outlook, because if we don't...

We will not only manage to weaken European production and give extra opportunities, commercial opportunities, to third countries, where the space for birds is infinitely worse than the current one we have in the European Union.

It is a Directive that requires a huge effort from European producers. In Spain alone, we can understand that the cost increases to around 600 million euros, but it must also be remembered that it has an economic impact that extends to the egg product industry and the food industry in general.

I therefore ask for the support of honourable Members for the amendment by the Group of the European People's Party to paragraph 2, which calls for a solution to be sought, at least, for those responsible industrial holdings that are in the process of transforming their holdings and will have almost completed this by January 2012.

We must support them in transforming these facilities and give them time to complete this process, thus avoiding irreparable damage to the farms and preventing a sudden shortage in the community market, which would consequently increase prices for consumers.
It is about respecting the Directive, giving an opportunity to the egg and egg product industry, while also respecting the right to animal welfare and the right of consumers to a reasonable price.

Mr President, I believe it is only fair to thank the rapporteurs, especially Mrs Grossetête and Mrs Dagmar Romberen from my own group, for the work they have done to get a regulation out of deadlock and make it useful, because this work has made it possible to include the right to public health as a legal basis.

And in order to have a new approach that allows us to lay the foundations that will guarantee citizens the security and quality they choose at any given moment, especially because it also allows for a clear regulation of the role of the states, both those of origin that have to make the payment and those in which treatment is received.

But I believe that we should not be satisfied with that alone, but rather that this should be the beginning of a much greater advancement that makes, as Mrs. Romperin said, of this Directive a mere formality, because the level of equality achieved in all the States makes it unnecessary for each citizen to travel to each country.

And in that struggle, we must obtain a standard that guarantees citizens' rights more effectively in relation to the care they must receive, including benefits, sensitivity, and security, beyond the mere right they already have to mobility between states.
Equality is what will make Union work, or else we will be taking very small steps.

Madam President, the Spanish Socialist delegation has voted in favour, as has the rest of our group, but I would not leave here without expressing my concern that these have been included in this Directive.
the issue of organ transplants, contrary to the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, as a result of the Council's persistent insistence on including transplants in this Directive.

I hope that this inclusion will have the enormous effectiveness of the good legislation that we approved in this very plenary session, both with the Transplant Directive and with the Action Plan, just a short time ago and with virtually unanimous support.

And I warn that we will be vigilant to ensure that the good work done by such successful organizations as the National Transplant Organization of Spain is not diminished by this inclusion, and certainly not with the intention of saving twenty thousand lives that we had both in the Transplant Directive and in the Action Plan, which, I repeat, we approved here.
Therefore, I make it clear and say that we will continue to monitor compliance with this Directive in that regard.
Mr President, today is also European Day against Sexual Health.
Ladies and gentlemen, the data is alarming. The World Health Organization estimates that more than 300 million people contract a sexually transmitted disease involuntarily each year.

In Europe, as the European Sexual Health Forum warns, there is a worrying increase in the number of unwanted pregnancies among teenagers, due to an excessive lack of education and information among our young people.

Indeed, as the Commission points out, there are various and diverse inequalities in Europe regarding access to sexual health services, depending on the country and, within these countries, depending on the citizens' income level.
A European strategy is needed to combat all of this.
Only five member states have plans in this regard, but in all of them, the number of unwanted pregnancies, sexually transmitted disease infections, and also the number of abortions has been reduced.
A common strategy that focuses on prevention in the educational field, expands information policies, increases efforts in family planning, and facilitates accessibility to contraceptive methods.
A comprehensive and ambitious strategy, free of taboos, to guarantee the right of every citizen to sexual health under the safest and healthiest conditions.
Mr President, in a time of great social tension, one cannot but warmly welcome the major social agreement in Spain between the government, the trade unions and the employers' associations.
This agreement is exemplary for Europe, where such milestones have not been achieved for a long time.

The arguments of Cándido Méndez, one of the main protagonists of that Spanish Pact, should also be taken into account. Last Tuesday, February 8, he attended the meeting of the Economic and Social Council in Brussels.
Mr. Candido then insisted on the need to extend consultation on a European scale and on the need to have the voice and initiatives of trade unions in our Europe.
this is how they should be

Mr President, while acknowledging the differences in terms of terrorism and immigration, I have observed that the European Union unfortunately operates on the basis of emergency situations, such as a serious air accident.

an attack or a mass landing of immigrants like the one currently happening in Lampedusa, where the exodus of citizens from Tunisia towards the Italian coasts could result in a chronicle of a death foretold.
The journey of hope can end in a cursed journey and will weigh on our conscience, on that of all those who witness these continuous uncontrolled flows and do not say enough with sufficient authority.
When it happens, we'll put our hands over our heads, but the next day we'll forget.

European citizens have the obligation and the right to know the truth that the Mediterranean strategy does not work, that the common migration policy will remain a dream as long as European countries do not commit to sufficient financial means for Frontex to be effective.
Talking costs nothing, but we have to act.
Do you really believe that Frontex, at present, can guarantee the security of European borders?
I don't think so.

Let us hope that the citizens of Tunisia, Egypt and other Maghreb countries do not decide en masse to seek a better future in Europe, but rather that they do so in their own countries, because that is what they have been fighting for, and we must help them achieve it.
Therefore, solidarity, responsibility, but above all, truth, when discussing a common European migration policy that is more necessary today than ever.

Madam President, it has already been said that the backbone of pension systems in Europe is and must continue to be the public system, because this is the only system that guarantees cohesion and the only one that also reduces the risks of poverty in our society.

It is still normative that in OECD countries, the highest levels of equity in citizens' income are found in pensions, or that, due to the crisis, private pensions lost 20% of their value in 2008 alone and are still, to this day, far from the required solvency levels.

All of this demonstrates that, at a time of unavoidable reforms, the sustainability of our pension system must be addressed in a cross-cutting manner, taking into account, among other factors, ambitious policies on birth rates or work-life balance.
ambitious policies on access to and retention of employment, or even immigration policies based on integration that also ensure, from a demographic point of view, the sustainability of our pensions.
Finally, I regret that the text does not set limits on the abuse of scholarship figures in companies, since, as a general rule, these are excluded from all types of social contributions.
In my opinion, this is essential for a whole new generation of workers who, if they are being asked to do more to have a decent pension, should also be made to suffer less to access decent work.

Mr President, Commissioner, we are at a key moment in the construction of the future cohesion policy, which, following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, focuses not only on economic and social aspects, but also on territorial ones.
Territorial cohesion aims for harmonious development among territories so that their citizens can make the most of their territorial distinctiveness.
But in order to achieve this goal, it is also necessary to make progress in the area of cooperation between the regions of the Union that are facing the same challenges and problems.

This is the goal pursued by the European Union Strategy for the Atlantic region: a common perspective to address the common challenges faced by the states in the region, including marine research, maritime surveillance, and environmental and economic challenges.

To achieve our objectives, it is necessary to adopt an integrated strategic approach that is in line with the 2020 Strategy and the European Union's policies for the period after 2013, especially with regional policy and maritime policy.
Ladies and gentlemen, first and foremost, it is necessary that this strategy be based on renewed multi-level governance, based on closer participation of public authorities.
regional and local authorities, Member States, the European Union and private sector stakeholders and civil society organisations, including interregional organisations and networks.

It is a very significant day to talk about equality between men and women, because we celebrate Women's Day, remembering those who fought a hundred years ago for labor and economic rights and for women's suffrage.
We have made great progress in these hundred years, but there is still much to be done, and true equality is still a dream, and discrimination against women is a reality.

I believe that each of us, men and women, can do much more to achieve the true emancipation of women, because there are many women in the world whose right to live is threatened, whose dignity is violated, and whose freedom is denied.
Allow me, on this Women's Day, to show my support and hope to all the women in the North African Revolution who are fighting for their democratic rights.
Because a woman is not worth half a man, neither in Arab countries nor anywhere in the world.
Therefore, we are worth the same and deserve the same.
And I will continue to fight to achieve it, and as long as that equality does not exist, Women's Day will continue to exist.
Although many people may not want to see it, it is a reality that women earn half of what men do, and that domestic violence primarily affects women and children.
And I repeat, we must continue to denounce all these facts in this Parliament, and of course, I promise that I will continue to work.
Mr President, I wish to express my agreement with the opinion of the Members who have spoken here this morning and who insist on respect for Parliament and the Commission.
Therefore, my modest vote in favor will depend on the European Council's willingness to admit the role of the aforementioned institutions.
Because the new mechanism we are talking about must be an important component of economic governance, led by a European Union.
capable of ensuring coherence between the common economic policy, which must set clear, precise and limited objectives, and this stability instrument.

In other words, we must avoid at all costs that this effort in which we are embarked ends up in the intergovernmental route, which is a dead end or the route of the predominance of a few States, because all of this would thwart the reform.
Dear colleagues, Europe is built stone by stone, and this is one of the stones that reinforce and balance this delicate edifice.
There are essential points that need to be improved, so we must send the report back to the Commission.
The interparliamentary dialogue of this report does not end here, however.
The initial proposal was bad.
This is what consumer associations were telling us at both national and European level.
And, in particular, my esteem for the work of the Consumers' Union of Asturias and its president, the indefatigable Dace Alonso.
