We have managed to have the general principle of maximum harmonisation of the old Article 4 rejected.

It must be said very loudly that maximum harmonization, by establishing the same protection in all Member States, would mean a reduction in the protection of many consumers, since there is a greater tradition of protecting consumer rights in various countries.

I would like to emphasize, in any case, that it is essential to ensure that the list of unfair contractual terms is not exhaustive, so that each Member State can increase the number of terms it considers unacceptable and invalid in contracts with consumers.

Reverse the burden of proof for individual clauses, so that it is the merchants who have to demonstrate that the clauses deviating from the generally established terms have been negotiated individually, and that the contractual clauses must be expressed in a clear and comprehensible form.
We continue to oppose the establishment of maximum harmonisation in relation to unfair terms.
The Eurobarometer tells us that 79% of traders believe that full harmonisation in this field will have little or no effect on their activities abroad.
Mr President, Commissioner, allow me, first of all, to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Schwab and Mrs Gerhardt on the excellent work they have done.
and a general reflection.
It's not that protectionism is increasing, but rather that it's about not cutting rights that already exist in some of the member states.
Because if we want and pursue establishing a genuine internal market for relations between businesses and consumers, we must
establish, in parallel, a balance between the high level of protection of consumer rights and the defense of business competitiveness.
This balance involves agreeing on a minimum harmonization and allowing Member States to maintain or adopt additional regulations that improve consumer protection.
We cannot allow the adoption of a community standard to result in the lack of protection for many consumers and users.
I am pleased that negotiations in the European Parliament have improved, but I would like to emphasize that the rights that have been established so far should not be curtailed.

Mr. President, many experts are telling us that the next crisis may be an energy crisis and that, furthermore, either we are not doing the necessary homework to avoid it or we are not doing it at the necessary speed to avoid it.
This coming Saturday, the World Forum for Nature is calling on everyone to make a small gesture towards sustainability.
Many citizens will turn off their lights for an hour and many public administrations will follow their lead.
But it is not enough.
Europe cannot continue to depend on energies that are not its own, that are distant or insecure.
We need to help states build a new energy model in which renewable energies are at the heart of the new one.
And we must also support the awareness of new consumption patterns, because, without a doubt, renewables and efficiency are the keys to future sustainability.

Finally, I want to appeal to all the countries of the Union to join that call, to that will of five of them, including Spain, to increase CO2 emission reductions to 30% because in this way we would demonstrate that Europe, in addition to being at the forefront of freedom and rights, is also at the forefront of its commitment to the sustainability of the planet.
Madam President, most of the times I have spoken in this Parliament, I have done so to denounce violence against women and, once again, I am here to fight against it.

I must say that not only do I not tire of it, but I consider it essential to continue speaking publicly about this violation of human rights, since there is no cause that can be defended without a sounding board, and this Parliament is the best one.

It is the loudspeaker that I have at my disposal to defend all those women who suffer abuse daily and who need us, legislators, to pressure states to punish aggressors according to the severity of the crime and also to help the victims.

When it is estimated that a quarter of European women have suffered gender-based violence at least once in their lives and that children have also suffered to the same extent, I believe it is impossible not to call for greater commitment, such as that recognized by the Commission in its action plan.

I believe it is necessary to keep insisting again and again on leaving victims behind, as we already did in the European Protection Order for Victims, for which I was the rapporteur, and I hope that it will become a reality as soon as possible.
This report has enjoyed broad consensus and support from the outset, demonstrating that, when it comes to addressing domestic violence, which affects all members of society,
family, children, elderly people, women and men, should not be a reason for political opportunism, because we are all honored to make progress in solving this social scourge.

The first thing is not to remain silent and the second thing is to get to work, because, although we have been talking about gender violence for decades, we have not been able to reduce the number of deaths.

We must be doing something wrong and, therefore, it is time to forget about demagogy and move from words to actions, providing more help and the necessary action so that women can live with dignity and security.
And security, let all the victims know that I will always be here to continue lending them my voice until, together, we manage to defeat this...
A terrible enemy that sadly ends the lives of so many innocents. I say enough, enough already, and I ask all of you to say it with me.
Mr President, Commissioner, I agree with you that we must listen to the citizens and regain confidence in the European project.
That is why today can be a great day for Europe and the construction of European society.

Because with the approval of these reports, we are not only moving towards the reactivation of the single market, a key element in the face of the current economic crisis, but we are also responding to the demands of citizens who are calling for more Europe and the strengthening of social rights.
Europe must respond to new global challenges and ensure that the European economy becomes a highly competitive social market economy that generates significant growth with more and better jobs.

But this objective must be based on the inclusion of a social clause in all legislation related to the internal market, which places citizens at the center of our attention and priority and strengthens their social rights.
Finally, I would like to ask the Commission to present these proposals as soon as possible.
Mr. President, bluetongue has been a constant threat to our livestock and, with it, also to our public health.

A disease that we fought against through the use of live vaccines, which involves the creation of restricted zones for animal movement, because the use of these vaccines can lead to unwanted circulation of the virus in non-infected animals.

For these reasons, the use of vaccination was limited to the area where infected animals had previously been found, creating a double disadvantage for farmers: the disease on the one hand, and the restrictions on the other.

But all these problems seem to be avoidable through the new inactivated vaccine, which, in addition to preventing the disturbances that can be caused in the internal livestock market, allows for the development of new and, most importantly, broader prevention strategies in the fight against this disease.
For all these reasons, it is of vital importance for this sector that we amend the Directive to allow its use and, moreover, that we do so as soon as possible.

Ladies and gentlemen, compliance with what our Treaties require, especially regarding the correlation tables, cannot serve as an excuse for this regulation not to come into force before the summer, because with our delay, with their delay, we would only be harming the farmers.

Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank the Committee on Petitions for the work it has carried out following the complaint lodged by FEEPEX, which is the Spanish Organisation of Fruit and Vegetable Producers and Exporters, based on the report published in 2007 by OLAF, the European Union's anti-fraud agency.

I believe that the conclusions of that report are crystal clear and more than justify the fact that the European Commission had already set to work a long time ago to clarify the operation of the entry price system with regard, at least, to the tomato sector.

However, not only has the Commission not intervened to address the potential pitfalls that may arise from the Entry Price Regulation in force, but it has also negotiated a new agricultural agreement with Morocco without first resolving the shortcomings of the existing import regime.

Ladies and gentlemen, it is high time for the European Commission to take its responsibilities seriously and start investigating where the fraud is occurring, and eventually request the recovery of unpaid customs duties.
I think that in no way should a new agreement with Morocco be ratified without the details we have outlined being resolved.

Our goal is not to prevent the signing of international agreements, but to ensure that these agreements do not seriously harm the interests of European productions and that the rules signed in these agreements are respected.

As regards the new agreement with Morocco, the European fruit and vegetable sector only asks for guarantees that the effective implementation of the agreed measures will be carried out, and this is only possible through the reform of the current entry price system.
We cannot have a new agreement with Morocco until we have a new entry price system.
We cannot ratify that agreement that the Commission has already closed.

Moreover, if it is the responsibility of the Member States to carry out this control, a significant financial effort should be required of them. However, it is also true that we have been demanding for a long time that there be a European customs border system, similar to the one the United States has, to ensure effective control.

Mr President, Commissioner, dealing with this report in Parliament has been complex, mainly because it involves measures that require the approval of the World Trade Organization, and the preliminary proposal that the Commission sent to Parliament is different from the one sent to Geneva.
We believe that it is necessary to help Pakistan, we understand that exceptional trade preferences can be granted, provided that they take into account the sensitivities of the
the European industry and, in particular, the textile sector, which in communities such as the Valencian Community in Spain are severely suffering the consequences of the crisis.

But this report has allowed us to verify that the measures that can be taken within the framework of international trade probably cannot be addressed with the urgency that these acts require, so we should learn for the future.

Help Pakistan, yes, but not with the Commission's original proposal, as it does not take into account the effects of the European industry in terms of the implementation deadlines for sensitive products.
I would even delay the implementation of these measures because if they do not coincide with the pending text scheduled for approval by the WTO, we would be behind schedule.
Therefore, we consider it unacceptable to maintain this proposal and we think we will have to vote against it.
Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating all those who have made it possible to reach an agreement.

It is an agreement that we should all congratulate ourselves on because it affects the daily lives of all citizens, but, in the constructive spirit that characterizes me, I would like to make a few points.
First of all, I would like to draw attention to the importance of providing accurate, relevant, but above all, comprehensible and uniform information.
for consumers about the components of textile products. Comprehensive information is useless if citizens are unable to decipher it.
We have achieved a positive step, necessary but not sufficient. We should go further and protect citizens who could become more vulnerable.
Ladies and gentlemen, it is essential to establish a European sizing system based on body measurements, because the first thing we encounter when we go to buy a garment is the size.
That is why we should be much more ambitious and aim for size harmonization.
Mr President, three comments on the situation created around the cucumbers.
I am of German descent and have great affection for that country, but it is evident that the German authorities have acted in this case with haste and imprudence.

On the other hand, if we analyze the European response, we notice that the one developed by the Food Safety Authority and the Commission has been weak, very subdued and imprecise, and has not been able to coordinate or direct.
Third, those affected are entitled to financial compensation quickly.
But for now, I propose to this Parliament that we organize a major European gastronomy exhibition in Brussels or here in Strasbourg, based precisely on cucumbers.
We must vindicate the lost honor of cucumber producers, a phrase that the German writer Heinrich Böll found appealing.
Europe is the appropriate setting for this.
Mr President, first of all, it is obligatory to express sincere condolences for the twenty-three victims who have already died, twenty-two in Germany and one in Sweden.
And it has to be said that this crisis is the most glaring proof that the European Union must significantly improve its food alert system and its internal coordination.
The Member States involved have demonstrated slowness, inefficiency, ineffectiveness, and, at this point, even after twenty-three deaths, we still do not know where the problem is coming from.

The European Commission must seriously reflect on the problems caused by its irresponsible actions or inaction during times of crisis such as the current one, resulting in cases of economic ruin and the destruction of jobs that were once secure.

of unemployment, powerlessness and, of course, a health crisis with extremely high health risks for the population. Because while you, from the Commission, were echoing irresponsible statements from regional authorities,

German companies were very uninformed and quite irresponsible, with names and surnames of Spanish farms, meanwhile, the population continued to be unknowingly exposed to the bacteria, believing they were avoiding it, citizens were more exposed than ever to eating something that could harm them.

The European Commission should propose to ministers today, at the Agriculture Council meeting in Luxembourg at 2 p.m., that part of the 2 million euros that exist as unused remnants of the common agricultural policy be used.
We need those 2 million euros to repair as much of the damage as possible.
To do this, it is necessary to seek a legal loophole that allows it, a legal loophole that has already been found on other occasions, such as mad cow disease or dioxins, and that should be found now.
Therefore, Commissioners, Ministers, today in Luxembourg you must live up to your responsibility.

The German authorities, moreover, given the irresponsible accusations made, should support this economic solution, without a doubt and from the outset, and also finance, with their own funds, communication campaigns to restore the lost consumer confidence in fruit and vegetable production.

Mr President, Commissioner, nothing we do here or in the European Union will bring back the dead, and I hope that what is being done will prevent there being more victims and stop the chain of sick people who are suffering without having done anything to deserve it.

We don't know the causes, probably, but we do know some things that we must name. There has been negligence in political actions and there has been negligence in the German federal government. It cannot act as if Hamburg were a state on another continent.

The arrogance that Mrs. Merkel and her Health Minister have, and their unusual tendency to address other states, if it had been translated into diligence and efficiency in coordination, some of the things that have happened would not have occurred.

And that negligence has had criminal consequences on a state that has been the Spanish state and on its most important sector, agriculture, and has led to family ruin for thousands of people and small business owners and has discredited the economy for a long time.
I ask you to go to the Council today and demand full compensation for those affected, since we cannot ask for life for the dead.
and that the control systems are reviewed.
And that Mrs. Merkel be held accountable.
And that he be asked for less arrogance and more diligence.
And that she be held responsible for some damage she has caused.
You cannot ignore that Hamburg is in your state.
He cannot ignore his responsibilities.
You can't hide behind a decentralized and federal state to cause the damage you've caused.

A little more humility, a little more good management and a little less conservatism would have been very helpful so that this crisis did not get out of hand and Spain and other farmers in the south did not have to suffer its painful consequences.
Review the controls, review the alert systems and demand accountability, because in Spain we are demanding it, Commissioner, from you, from the Council and from the German State.
Mr President, we are facing a public health problem, an epidemic, as the Commissioner has said, and in response to this, people have been looking for culprits, not the cause.

The system has not worked; we have twenty-two dead, 1 affected, and we do not know the cause three weeks later, and, appealing to a precautionary principle without scientific basis—I repeat, without scientific basis—Spain is being blamed.
Ladies and gentlemen, Spanish cucumbers were not contaminated.
they were contaminated, they were not contaminated, I repeat this because I have heard some contrary versions around here.
But to give you an idea of the importance of what these words have sparked, 300 jobs could be affected, a loss of trust.
An epidemic knows no borders.

I agree with you, Commissioner, it knows no borders. We are calling for accountability for what has not been done, for what we must do immediately, because Germany has a risk problem at the moment, it has the highest number of affected people, but Spain is not to blame.
We demand compensation.
What is important and what unites us here today are the victims, because no one should feel as unprotected as we European consumers feel today.
And it is out of respect for the victims that we need clarity and accountability.

And it is my responsibility to denounce the German authorities who unjustly and hastily accused Spanish cucumbers and, specifically, the cooperatives in Málaga and Almería, which were exemplary farms and will not recover from these accusations.
Thousands of jobless families are asking why, why they need an answer and, above all, what their future will be, not only in Andalusia, but throughout agricultural Europe.

Therefore, and trusting that experts will quickly find a solution, I demand that the Commission, when it speaks with the Council today, requests immediate economic and moral measures for all producers who, from Andalusia and from all over Europe, look towards us with indignation, but with hope.
Mr President, instead of giving priority to European research and collaboration, the German authorities have slandered and harmed cucumber producers and others.
And still, no one in Germany has resigned or offered reparations commensurate with the damage caused.
It is Germany that has a serious credibility problem.
Mrs. Merkel's treatment of the southern countries in terms of agriculture and finance is intolerable.
Someone said that Merkel was a disciple of Adenauer and Kohl.
none of that lacks credibility moran
Mr President, it is no coincidence that Spain, Italy, Greece, Ireland, Portugal and other countries all share our reluctance to readily accept the so-called Eurovision.
The coincidence, the criticism is due to our status as peripheral countries, who will ultimately be the ones to pay this unique tax that will be collected by the central European Union states.
The reasoning behind the Eurovignette is riddled with contradictions, and the supporting discourse is becoming increasingly fragile.

Although the rationality of internalizing external costs is accepted as a starting point, in the end, the idea of penalizing only heavy-duty vehicles to alleviate congestion, while leaving tourists out, does not hold up. This is because the old adage of "the polluter pays" is being applied in a discriminatory manner.

On the other hand, ladies and gentlemen, the Eurovignette, which was conceived as a source of funding for infrastructure, will ultimately only allocate 15% to the funding of trans-European networks, and not in a mandatory manner.

but as a simple recommendation so that the Minister of Finance of the time can distill the collected funds in the way he deems most convenient for the interests of his country, within the broad chapter of infrastructure.
The end result will be nothing other than another blow to road freight transport, which is currently the only mode that is enabling the internal market.
This is the reality, ladies and gentlemen, a reality that is much more harsh in a situation of economic crisis.

In this sense, the competitiveness of European products in global markets cannot afford experiments that could contribute to further deteriorating the precarious situation of the European economy by imposing new added costs.

And, of course, the food crisis, which has recklessly been blamed on Spanish products, has resulted in unfair penalties and enormous losses to those affected by the Eurovignette for freight transporters and farmers of related crops.
These are the reasons, ladies and gentlemen, why the Spanish delegation of the European Party will vote against this draft Directive.
You will all understand, dear colleagues, that in taking the chair, I express my sorrow and consternation at the passing of Jorge Semprún, which occurred a few hours ago at the age of 87.

At Jorge Sanprún we celebrate the man who was a prisoner in the Buchenwald concentration and extermination camp, the fighter against the Nazi forces in France and against the Franco dictatorship in my country, Spain.
We also celebrate the most notable committed writer, a collaborator in particular of our program The European Book of the Year, and we also celebrate the convinced Europeanist politician.

He also mourned his death as a colleague and friend, and I will ask President Buzek to send a message of condolences and solidarity to his family and the Spanish government, which I am sure we all share.
the creation of an economic governance space governed by the principles of federalism adapted to European integration.
We can no longer close our eyes.
It is incoherent to have a single currency and, at the same time, lack the fiscal and financial instruments that this currency requires.
In concrete terms, therefore, we need the issuance of European debt, a clear rejection of competition between the debt issuance of the States, the creation of a genuine European public treasury, the
harmonisation of fiscal policies that guarantee equality for citizens, combat tax fraud, and help define a progressive European social policy based on effective public services.
These ideas are, I will be told, elementary.
But you have to repeat and repeat them, because no one listens.
And precisely because they do not listen, those dark times of which the poet Bertolt Brecht spoke occur.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the current economic and financial crisis we are experiencing highlights the need for regional policy as the best instrument for reducing the development disparities between regions and states.
At the same time, we can recover the positive image of Europe that citizens have recently associated only with tough austerity plans and social cuts.

The future cohesion policy, a pillar of solidarity, of the European project and of social justice, must take into account the following priorities: first, to strengthen social cohesion and integrate the challenges posed by the 2020 Strategy; second, to take into account the needs and characteristics.

geographical regions, especially the most disadvantaged ones. Third, maintain the principle of gradualism in the allocation of funds, so that regions do not abandon the objective of convergence, avoiding abrupt changes in the allocation of aid, and fourth, promote a system
equitable.
Finally, ladies and gentlemen, the authorities are implementing tough budget adjustment policies.
That is why the Union's support is necessary.
I hope the Council takes good note.

In defense of fundamental rights, I call on the responsible institutions to review the designation of San Sebastián as European Capital of Culture, because I believe it has been chosen based on political criteria, which constitutes discrimination against the other cities that aspired to the title.

The president of the court said that it was chosen to support the peace process and that I know that in Spain there is a terrorist organization called ETA that, to this day, has not abandoned its weapons and that two months ago it managed to have its political arm, Bild, govern, among other municipalities, that of San Sebastián.
I don't think that from Europe we should give such a powerful voice to those who do not condemn terrorist violence and will use propaganda to distribute blame between victims and murderers.
Where is the right to freedom and dignity?
Certainly not in San Sebastián, where our colleagues like Mayor Oreja Iturgaiz, Salva, or myself have to be escorted.
I believe in the culture of life, not in the culture of the shot.
Can there be true culture without freedom?
No and a thousand times no.
And when San Sebastián becomes a city free for all, let it reapply for the title, and in the meantime, let them learn the culture of respect for those who think differently.
Because tomorrow they might deserve it, but today, with Batazuna and its heirs in the institutions, they do not deserve it.
Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for the fruitful collaboration they have provided me with in drafting it.
And I say the same thing about the other fellow deputies on the Committee of this Parliament.
Sixty years ago, the European Coal and Steel Community was created; there is no better way to commemorate this event than to debate energy infrastructure in Europe now.

Today, the European Union has clearly defined the objectives of its common European internal market policy: promoting renewable energies as a means or instrument for combating climate change, ensuring supply security, and diversifying its sources.

The Treaty of Lisbon has dedicated a title to energy, Article 21, where these commitments I have just mentioned are formulated and, in addition, the promotion of the interconnection of energy networks.
Well, the objective of the report we have prepared is aimed at correcting energy infrastructures that, in the opinion of the European Commission, are outdated and poorly interconnected.
Thus, for example, we are seeing a spectacular increase in electricity generation from wind in the North Sea and the Baltic, with the immense potential for renewable energy in southern Europe.
Europe and North Africa, with the problems arising from large-scale electricity storage, the needs for recharging electric vehicles, among many other urgent issues.
All of this is impossible to address today if we do not devise new networks and new connections, both within the European Union and with third countries.
Therefore, in the coming years, the focus will be on determining the necessary infrastructure and establishing the criteria for selecting projects of European interest.

b) by eliminating energy islands  
c) by ensuring the execution of these projects within reasonable timeframes and mediating formulas to resolve the contentious issue of the
authorisation and licensing procedures in the Member States, ensuring financing that attracts and boosts private investment, without prejudice to the public support that is necessary.
Energy efficiency and savings, as well as smart grids, are central ingredients in the new design incorporated into the report, because we have
It has been believed that by reducing energy demand, dependence on imports can be decreased, with a consequent effect on infrastructure needs.
A fundamental concern of this report from the outset has been the processing of licenses and authorizations intended to allow the execution of the necessary works.
These, at present, are eternalized.
And they are concerned about the opposition of the populations to see towers or other types of facilities grow in their neighborhood.

To resolve this conflict, consideration has been given to early information for citizens and establishing a warning system in the event that the authorities of a state do not respond to a request within a reasonable time frame.
We are facing ambitious goals that require the cooperation of everyone.

respect and force an agreement with the Council of Ministers and this Parliament to allow aid to the poorest to be preserved beyond that date.
Thanks to European aid, food banks have done remarkable social work that should not be paralyzed by the selfishness of some governments.
This work has benefited 13 million people and, thanks to it, with minimal effort we have managed to make the common agricultural policy a little more important.

Mr. President, the Regulation we are debating today is not perfect. It cannot, on its own, fix the problems of a sector with structural issues and also due to the economic context we are experiencing with short-term problems.
But this Regulation, while not perfect, is a step forward, decisive and in the right direction.

Because if in recent times we have all realized that there is no perfect market, it was very necessary to introduce into this game, where, in addition, we are playing with people's food security, all the regulatory elements we could and protection for our producers.

It was very necessary that we allow the obligatoriness of contracts with a minimum term and a maximum volume, at least as a defense instrument, because, of course, our producers do not start with the same negotiating strength when facing distribution, intermediaries or collectors.
There is still much work to be done.
We must improve the safety nets and make them more agile and more effective.
We must strive to further integrate the sector into the value chain, ensure that quotas are not distributed, especially in certain areas, and promote quality policies.

But, without any doubt, with our positive vote and with all that remains to be done, today many livestock farmers will be able to see this Parliament that has defended their labor rights, the most basic of all, which is the right to be able to live with dignity from the income of their work.
Group B has well pointed out the disastrous consequences that the approval of this Agreement would entail.
Because this agreement, which extends quotas for certain fruit and vegetable products, is completely meaningless when the figures in the present Agreement are not respected.

It is worth noting that the Spanish Federation of Fruit and Vegetable Producers and Exporters reported to the Committee on Petitions, specifically of this Parliament, the massive influx of tomatoes through Perpignan at a price lower than that set in the agreement.
Illegal situations such as the one described place the European farmer at a competitive disadvantage.
It should also be added that our farmers must adhere to strict quality, environmental, and social standards that our Moroccan partners do not always respect.
To conclude, I will mention the question of the Sahara.
According to the United Nations Charter, the Sahara is an autonomous territory and the exploitation of its resources must benefit precisely the local population.
Moreover, it constitutes a zone over which the UN does not recognize the sovereignty of the Kingdom of Morocco.
The European Union must ensure compliance with international law.

I am in favor of an agreement with Morocco, in favor of an agreement that establishes rigorous control mechanisms from the European Union in relation to quotas and prices, an agreement that fights against dumping, that does not exploit Moroccan farmers and, above all, that dignifies our European farmers.
It is, of course, not this agreement.

This year, the Committee on Petitions of the European Parliament requested the European Commission to modify the entry price system for fruits and vegetables in the Union, a system that is facilitating the fraudulent entry of productions from third countries, as stated by the Union's own anti-fraud agency, OLAF.
They are mainly Moroccan tomatoes.
The same request was included in a declaration signed last year by the governments of Spain, France, and Italy.

This, this fraud, is resolved by amending the Regulation implementing the Common Organisation of the Market in Agricultural Products, because aligning the Customs Code does not solve the problem, Commissioner.

For several years, I have been advocating within the Popular Party for the need to halt new concessions to Morocco until the European Union equips itself with the necessary instruments to ensure compliance with the current agreement.
The European Commission argues that it is the Member States that must ensure control of imports.

However, what the Commission does not say is that the entry price system, as it currently stands, prevents national customs authorities from properly tracing the prices declared by importers to verify that there are no irregularities.

They are modifying the Regulation implementing the CMO for agricultural products, and we will have solved part of the problem, because, if not, the legal loophole in European regulations prevents national authorities from doing their job properly.
Once again, dear colleagues, the debate about a summit.
Many have been held, all announced with great fanfare, trying to create an anticipation that is getting smaller every day.
They are becoming less credible because they are not contributing to solving the crisis.
Summits where the same agreements are reiterated time and time again.

It should be known that, as long as there is no progress in political union and in strengthening this Parliament and the executive power of the European Commission, summits will be repeated, but the economic crisis will worsen.
In a telegraphic manner, two ideas: first, the need to emphasize that responsible solidarity and the fulfillment of duties are the
materials with which Europe is being built. The second, that the use of structural funds that are unspent be authorized immediately.
These amounts can easily allow for the fight against the unemployment figures of young European citizens.

Madam President, from the European Parliament I want to pay tribute today to all women, who, despite the fact that we have made great progress since that March of 1911, when women took to the streets to demand the right to vote and better working conditions, I believe that women's equality is still far from being achieved.
Today women can work without having to ask anyone's permission, but in many cases they still earn less than men for similar work, which is unacceptable.
We must also remember the women in the rural world, whose work is ignored.
I believe that another uncomfortable reality, but one that must continue to be denounced, is violence against women.

This year alone, there has already been an excessive number of women murdered, not to mention the serious threats made by those who believe they have the right to exercise physical or psychological violence against them.
It is time to say enough and to say it loud and clear.
From this Parliament, I reiterate my commitment to the European Protection Order for Victims and to the Victims Directive presented by the Commission, which will be voted on, God willing, next June.
Mr President, we also have to say, and I would like to remind you, that maternity continues to be an obstacle to women's career progression, and I believe this is a trend that needs to change.
Mr. President, I want to send a message of hope and, with many women, with the help of more and more men, we must move forward on the path of equality, of opportunities, rights, and also of duties.
We have come a long way, but there is still much to be done.
I have to admit that I don't believe deeply and absolutely in quotas, but I have to tell you that something has to be done and I agree.
With many of my colleagues and, of course, with Mrs. Reding, to open this debate and to move forward on this path so that women regain the place they deserve, and you can count on my help for that.

Mr. President, at a time of economic crisis and budget cuts that is affecting public health and in which, as in the case of the community where I live, research centers like the Príncipe Felipe, specialized in diabetes, are left without funding, this Resolution is more timely than ever, it is absolutely appropriate.

We need a common European strategy against diabetes and we need a Council recommendation that tells the States that they have to increase research, including with stem cells, that they have to coordinate their results to optimize them, that they have to establish programs for healthy eating and lifestyle habits.

In short, we must prioritize people's health above all else, and in this case, investigating, coordinating, and implementing national programs coordinated by the Commission, while demanding results on diabetes, is a way to guarantee the quality of life of Europeans and ensure their very survival.

If we allocate more money to this, some will be a little more demanding in terms of payment, but those who are having problems now will certainly have a better quality of life, and we, as States, as Council and as Commission, will be fulfilling one of our obligations, which is to safeguard the health of our citizens.
Mr President, of the many issues that this debate raises, I would like to highlight that of the emissions trading market, a market that was certainly born with defects.
But today, the limitation of rights and the economic crisis have meant a drastic reduction in the price of carbon, that is, the price is so low that it is cheap to pollute.
It is therefore urgent to reform the design of a policy on that market, because its deterioration threatens all green efforts, the entire green policy of the European Union.
If emission rights are not valued, the increase in emissions is being encouraged. Polluting industries will not invest in new techniques, and what is worse,
The funding of important projects, such as those related to energy efficiency or carbon storage plants, will be jeopardized.
This is the risk.
It is up to us, the Commission and Parliament, to conjure it up.
Mr President, few asylum seekers are permanently resettled in Europe.
My country, Spain, has barely begun the experience.
The cases are, however, of urgent necessity.
The deputies have verified this on the ground during a trip to the Iraqi camps of Palestinian origin in Syria. The news that reached us immediately from Tunisia also confirms this.
Another more institutional aspect is the balance of power between Parliament and the Council.
Our rapporteur, the valiant Ruiz Tavares, there are many good parliamentarians, but few with as much tenacity as Ruiz.
Mr Tavares has fought to ensure the European Parliament retains the new powers gained after the Lisbon Treaty was passed.
I cannot forget the ongoing work carried out by UNHCR, without which success would not have been possible either.
UNHCR has made us all aware of the urgency of the report so that the funds can be used as soon as possible, now that they are so needed.
And finally, thank you very much, Commissioner, and I hope that we will also give you and your good heart the satisfaction of pushing through the asylum package next month.

The European social model, of which we are so proud, is not only based on our pension, education, and healthcare systems, but also on a way of understanding the balance between employers and employees within companies.

The labor reform that the Spanish government has approved without dialogue and without consensus breaks with that social model and distances us from the objectives of the 2020 Strategy, both in terms of job creation and in terms of job quality.
Labour reform alone does not create jobs; economic growth does.
What a labor law does define, however, are the conditions under which workers enter companies, the conditions under which they remain in them, and the conditions under which they leave them.
And with this reform, 80% of workers will be left unprotected because they will not be subject to collective agreements, and they can be fired due to a decrease in company revenue.
Because they can unilaterally modify their schedules, it is clear that workers will enter with greater precariousness, remain in the labor market with more fear, and leave it with less compensation.

That is why this reform, which attacks the European social model and bets on the competitiveness of the Spanish economy only in relation to workers' conditions, deserves a general strike, such as the one that must be called tomorrow in Spain in defense of this social model.

Mr President, Mr Barroso, let me begin by saying that the Spanish delegation of the European People's Party finds it appropriate and endorses the two packages you have presented today, both the labour package and the solidarity aid for Greece, which is closely related to the coherence of your approach.
It is undeniable, ladies and gentlemen, that we are living through difficult times and events every day remind us that the crisis is still far from being resolved.
The focus of attention has inevitably returned to Spain.
The alarms in the markets have been triggered without justification, fueled in part by statements that I believe, Mr. President, are inopportune.
One is in the context of an important election, in which both contenders cite my country as a dialectical element of confrontation.
Of course, we do not appreciate any of the references.
On the other hand, some people, in order to divert attention from their own problems, also deal with us with little political tact.
Today here too, some have been acting with finesse, as the Italians would say, and there has been a certain lack of political delicacy.
Ladies and gentlemen, the situation in the markets does not reflect Spain's strength.
We are a solvent country with the full capacity to meet our debts.
Spanish debt remains below the European Union average and the Spanish Government is fully committed to meeting the deficit targets agreed with the European Union.
Mr Rajoy has never said, Mr Svoloda, that he cannot meet the targets set by the European Union.
He has said the opposite, that he is willing to fulfill each and every one of those objectives, and he reiterates it every day.

In the few months since it took office, the Spanish Government has adopted and will continue to adopt very ambitious measures to ensure fiscal consolidation and lay the foundations for improved competitiveness, job creation, and growth.
The IMF's forecasts, by the way, from yesterday, the IMF itself admits, predate the analysis of the decisions and measures taken by the Spanish government at present.

Other measures we have adopted include the general state budget for 2012, which, in our opinion, will ensure that the deficit target is met this year. The organic law on budgetary stability this month.
The reform of the financial sector will undoubtedly also contribute to financial institutions having to allocate more than 50 million euros to developing countries.
In summary, Spain is meeting the objectives set by the Union and the Commission, and what we ask for is responsibility from everyone.

We need to save ourselves together and Spain with everyone, without any doubt, and not contribute in any way to criticism of one or the other, or are we all countries capable of being together and contributing to growth and the new economy, or, if not, it will naturally be difficult for us to move forward on the terms proposed by the Commission.
Now it's my turn. Do you want to make Mr. Rajoy, the President of the Government, the main character?
I think that's fine, I wouldn't have any problem.
But Mr. Rajoy is not the protagonist of the crisis.

The protagonist of the crisis is the legacy received by the Spanish socialist, communist, and green left, which has left the worst legacy ever left by any government, when they received the best legacy ever had by any government.
Mr. President, this morning I read in a major German newspaper that Spain and Argentina are in a dispute related to an oil company.
This is simply the wrong way to approach the matter.
The conflict is between Europe and Argentina and, beyond that, with that great European value which is legal certainty and its respect in international commercial relations.

European institutions have excellent legal experts who can find the appropriate instruments in Community law, whether primary or secondary, to neutralize the arbitrariness of the Argentine authorities.
I am a modest professor of Public Law and I offer to collaborate with them.
The credibility of the European Union before its citizens is currently at stake.

Mr President, in the Committee on Agriculture we share the ultimate goal of this Directive, which is to try to guide the composition of our energy mixes through taxation, but we are facing a very complex and difficult debate.

We are full of challenges economically, socially, and environmentally, and it is important to maintain those balances that make us advance more environmentally, yes, but that also do not harm us economically and that do not create greater social crises than the ones we are already experiencing.
This is the case with agriculture.

As everyone knows, energy costs are increasingly a very important part of the fixed costs of our agricultural holdings, at a time when, moreover, we are in a debate that combines the crises of the raw materials markets with a perspective of requesting aid and health and environmental needs that reduce their profitability margins.
That is why we have fundamentally asked for two things.

The first, the maintenance of zero-rate deductions in the energy component, now linked to the drafting and implementation of energy efficiency and savings strategies in rural areas, and the incorporation of
agriculture within sectors considered at risk of carbon leakage, in order to also be able to access the deductions allowed in the CO2 emissions bracket.
In other words, a more environmentally demanding policy, but one that maintains the balances that make our rural areas viable at a time of change and uncertainty within them.
We are living through a major controversy that is fundamentally based on the concepts of austerity and growth.
If you listen to the noise that is being created, it would seem that the idea of growth is a bright invention of these days.
Nothing could be further from the truth.
In Europe, the Pact has been in effect since 1997, and it is precisely called the Stability and Growth Pact.

That is why a large part of the policies carried out by European institutions, such as those on regional cohesion and research, are growth-oriented policies that aim to promote the development and well-being of citizens.

Therefore, and I am addressing the Commission and the members of this Parliament who have the most opportunities to make themselves heard, we will not shy away from engaging in that debate, which we can face with our heads held high.
This is my minority opinion among the non-enrolled.
Madam President, allow me, first of all, to thank all my colleagues and, above all, the shadow rapporteurs, for their help with this report, which has made it much stronger.

We all know that the twentieth anniversary of the launch of the single market is being celebrated, which should be the driving force behind economic activity and growth in Europe, a key factor in overcoming the crisis and achieving the objectives of Europe 2020.

Over these twenty years, the construction of the internal market must be made compatible with its development within a broad framework of consumer protection, growth, and rights that generate dynamism.
and confidence, transparency, a basic principle of democracy and good governance, to which Commissioner Barnier referred this afternoon, and cooperation between the Commission and Parliament.
It is now time to develop the regulatory framework concerning the protection and training of consumers, and particularly of vulnerable consumers.
We know that the diversity of vulnerability situations, both endogenous and exogenous, makes it difficult to adopt a comprehensive legislative instrument.
This obliges us to address the problem of vulnerability from a cross-cutting analysis, which takes into account the different needs, capacities, and circumstances of consumers.
The Commission, being aware of the current shortcomings, has focused its strategy on improving consumer information and education.
While an ambitious proposal, it is not enough to protect vulnerable consumers, because their vulnerability stems precisely from their lack of assertiveness and understanding of the
information they receive or of the options available or of their lack of knowledge of the existing complaint and compensation systems, especially in the case of cross-border and online consumption.

For all these reasons, in order to address the shortcomings, that is, the problems, it is necessary to adopt a strategy to strengthen vulnerable consumers and for both the Commission and the Member States to introduce specific measures in their legislation to ensure adequate protection.

that goes beyond mere information, especially in those areas where the level has been shown to be higher and where the highest number of consumer complaints are registered, the financial sector, whose complexity means that potentially any consumer can become vulnerable.

Therefore, the financial services industry is urged to redouble its efforts to provide comprehensible, truthful information, with clear explanations and direct language about the nature of the products and services it offers. The food sector, in relation to advertising

foods high in fats, salt and sugar and children and young people, who are most susceptible to advertising for these foods. The transport sector, which often still struggles when vulnerable people travel, the energy sector and telecommunications

where the lack of transparency in some cases creates an additional difficulty for consumers, for example in the energy sector when determining the tariff that best suits their needs, in access to justice, where consumers may encounter difficulties in accessing the mechanisms
existing.
That is why we are asking the Commission and the Member States, and allow me to sound a warning note to the Spanish Minister for Justice, Mr Gallardon, not to backtrack on rights.
and it goes against the trend of these difficult times to use intelligence and good governance in favor of alternative dispute resolution in consumer matters.
Finally, it should be noted that any one of us can become a vulnerable consumer. Thank you very much and I would like to thank all the helpers for their assistance in strengthening this report.
Mr President, Commissioner, the truth is that I have a sense of desperation, almost of frustration, that I must share with someone else.
He's not going to allow me to do it with you this evening.

This is the third or fourth debate we have had recently in this House on the situation of youth unemployment across Europe, and debate after debate, while youth unemployment rates are soaring in some Member States, we are already close to the

of the active population rate, while many of them are already running out of any kind of social coverage or unemployment, while all of this is happening, while we are moving from a situation that is evolving from being worrying to

From the unsustainable to the dramatic. The Commission presents itself once again in this Parliament, in this Chamber, as if it were a political commentator, as if it were just another analyst, and not as the true government of the Union, which is what it is and, moreover, what we need.

Commissioner, governing means setting priorities, governing means setting priorities, taking the lead, and, moreover, with the aim of achieving a goal, an objective, and, furthermore, the Commission is not doing this.

Governing is not about making a simple restructuring of funds, or even doing it, announcing it to wash one's face before public opinion, but about raising an ambitious, lasting and rapid strategy to end youth unemployment.

Governing is not about resigning in the face of a youth unemployment rate above 20% and being satisfied with a pilot project of four million euros, which is ridiculous given the situation, given the magnitude of the problem we are facing.

We must not give in to the pressures of the College of Commissioners or of other member states of the Council that are trying to convince us that the only way out of this financial crisis, this new wave of recession, is by giving up wages, labor rights, or compensation, that our only future as a generation is one of precariousness.

Because if this were true, Commissioner, that we only gain competitiveness through precariousness and that we will only become more competitive by being more precarious, then Zimbabwe would be the most competitive country and it is not.
This is the case in Sweden, Finland, and Denmark, which are precisely characterized by a model of exemplary relationships and also by a model of labor rights and guarantees.
Mr. President, employment is much more than a right of citizenship; it is an instrument of connection with the system, an instrument of social integration.

And therefore, the more unemployment, the greater the political disaffection. And that's why, Commissioner, I won't accept that you talk about issues of competence in order to do nothing about youth unemployment.

Because, moreover, Commissioner, when you have had to interpret the Treaties in a lax manner to create, for example, the Financial Stability Fund, you have done so, and when the Treaties have had to be reformed to comply with or satisfy the delusions of a Member State regarding austerity, we have also done so.
So, what is it that I want to tell you?
There's the Youth Employment Guarantee, for example, you don't need to explain it to them.

Advocate for increased funding, use the European Social Fund as a tool if necessary, design a co-funded and solidarity-based implementation mechanism that helps those with the highest unemployment rates the most, push to further change this policy of social favoritism towards countries that are doing worse, and remember that behind every figure there is a person who is struggling.
So, do you think, like me, that the least important thing is who the competition is, because for the citizens as a whole, especially...
Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the INTA Committee for the work carried out, as well as the rapporteurs and the shadow rapporteurs.

In general, we are dealing with a good G+ Regulation that is necessary, particularly in some actions to control the rules for importing textile products that could harm the production of the European Union.
But we are concerned about the exclusion, starting in 2014, of certain countries classified as upper-middle-income countries, such as those in Latin America, from the GSP.
What happens with these middle-income countries that have undiversified exports?
diversified. Why not introduce a criterion for export diversification?

Because two speeds could be produced in this scenario, countries like Costa Rica, Cuba, and Ecuador would benefit from it, distinguishing themselves from potentially developed countries like China and Brazil.

Therefore, I believe that we must support a transition period and that amendments will be presented with this transition period to adapt to this situation for these countries and give them the opportunity to open trade negotiations and agreements so that they can benefit from it.

Mr President, I already supported Mrs Nadelcheva's report when I was able to accompany her on the mission to the Congo together with other parliamentarians, and I indeed saw that I have seen few peoples with a greater manifest will to make democracy and participate in it.
But a people, in order to believe in democracy, also needs to believe in its State and its Government, and that will not be possible only with electoral support or with external support.
They also need there to be a demand to fight corruption and to break the indecent paradox of living in poverty in one of the countries richest in resources in the world.

And it must be said and denounced that part of the violence they experience is imported or at least encouraged by those unscrupulous multinationals that, from Europe or other continents or other states, are capable of participating in corruption without caring about fostering struggles over those resources in order to gain the favor of those who govern certain territories.

That is why, Mrs. Ashton, although it is not strictly within your competence, I say that greater demands for traceability and transparency from European multinationals and others from other continents that collaborate there would be as useful for the development of that people as the aid we can provide at the electoral level and at the technical level.
Mr President, to the rapporteurs for the valuable work they have presented.

Ladies and gentlemen, we are now debating package 2, after having approved package 6, after almost all the heads of state and government agreed on two international treaties outside the established order.
communitarian, after many other European regulations have created more community authorities for banking supervision, stock market supervision, insurance supervision, and for economic system risks.
an array of texts and more texts, of reports, of proposals that address new economic valuation criteria, new procedures, new protocols.
procedures. Should we not stop and apply what we have already approved?
In the face of the instability experienced by the European continent, what is needed is just the opposite: stability and legal security.
We do not need a mishmash of successive legal findings.
I don't know, dear colleagues, if I am dreaming.
The situation that the rescue entails is very worrying.
Spanish citizens are not being told the whole truth about the new debt, which, by guaranteeing private debt, the Spanish government and state are assuming as public debt.
The Spanish government has requested aid that it previously said it did not want, and is presenting it ridiculously as a triumph, as some colleagues warned in this debate.
There is no triumph but failure with Banque and others.

I insist, there is no more correct policy for Europe than the one sponsored by the French Government, behind which parliamentary ranks must close, for we will not emerge from debt without harmonious growth of all and of the whole.

Supervision, as called for in the two reports, yes, all the supervision that is necessary, but essential growth, simultaneous, anti-speculative, also, as alluded to in some of the measures of both reports and other reports as well.
Please, clarity and transparency too, balance, as my colleague Sánchez Presedo said before.
Madam President, since I entered this Parliament, I have continually denounced female genital mutilation.
This silent and accepted crime that millions of women and girls around the world suffer from, seventy million, I repeat, seventy million.

An unbearable figure for anyone who stops to study the terrible consequences of these practices, which are hidden under the guise of psychological, health, and religious reasons, all of which are false.

The truth is that ablation, performed preferably on girls as young as fourteen and even one year old, can lead to death by hemorrhagic collapse and, at best, cause and bring about severe psychological consequences due to trauma.
From Europe, we must fight with all our strength to eradicate this violation of human rights, which undermines the right to equal opportunities and endangers health.
Ladies and gentlemen, this is about abuse, cruelty, torture against girls, and this degrading treatment also exists in Europe.
To do this, we must activate all the prevention mechanisms available in our legal system, and I encourage our judges to take action to prevent genital mutilation.
of girls in Europe, punishing those who carry them out, so that the law in Europe speaks with a single voice when it comes to combating mutilation on our soil.
Finally, I call on civil society and NGOs to actively engage in education and prevention campaigns.
There is still a long way to go, but many of us will not stop because we owe it to seventy million mutilated women.
Mr President, Commissioner, I am fully aware that one of the reasons we approved the milk package was precisely to adapt the sector to a market without milk quotas in 2015.

But it is also true that every time this liberalization date approaches, uncertainty in the sector increases due to the lack of a clear exit strategy, and the reasons why the sector demands prudence and reflection from us before making a decision also increase.

Reasons, for example, such as the belief in maintaining vineyard planting rights or maintaining sugar quotas, at least until 2020, reasons such as the uncertainty that exists in the sector about the real effects of the dairy package and about

We would have had time to conduct a serious evaluation of them and also reasons such as the uncertainty about the direction of the common agricultural policy and, especially, its budget, that is, about the part of the income that does not come from the markets and that affects our producers.

So, what we are asking you, Commissioner, to convey to Mr Cholos, is that we do not engage in a makeshift policy of dismantling our protection systems without a serious and rigorous analysis, because the effects on our producers are irreversible.

The end of the quota should be postponed until 2015, until a date that provides security to the sector and opens up an open and transparent debate on the regulation mechanisms, because the markets are still more unfair and the producers are increasingly defenseless.
Mr President, many Members of this Parliament have listened to the voice of the citizens, the voice of the street.
Commissioner, you have said that this is a yes or no agreement.
We Members of this Parliament also have a responsibility to vote 'yes' or 'no'.
And we say no because this agreement causes confusion, as is evident.
Intellectual property rights and the rights of internet users are not clarified.
Are we concerned about intellectual property rights?
And that's it.
Thus, ACTA is the solution.
No, there is no solution, because there are two issues to address - it is not a legal issue, but two political issues: a determination of the fight against counterfeiting and the
piracy and another new legislative framework for the digital environment, which we in the Socialist Group have repeatedly requested, and we are requesting it again.
it's your chance.
Do not turn your back on society, because tomorrow it will become hostile and you will have no way out.
If they improve, it is sometimes necessary to accentuate the chaos.
The sense of powerlessness was of such magnitude that, inevitably, Europe had to react and it has done so for the good of all, because the big winner of this past summit has been the euro.
And with this victory, hope has returned that Europe will emerge from its paralysis, moving from reflection to action.
At this summit, ladies and gentlemen, it was as necessary to adopt short-term measures to ensure financial stability as it was to adopt long-term measures to address the shortcomings of the Union.
In this case, the immediate was essential in order to continue working towards what was important.
It was imperative to send a message that the euro is a common, irrevocable, and irreversible project.

We welcome, ladies and gentlemen, such important decisions as the one that empowers the European Stability Mechanism to directly recapitalize banks, which will break the vicious circle between bank debt and sovereign debt, a thesis always defended, by the way, by the current Spanish government.
In addition, it will serve to intervene in the markets in support of the public debt of countries that meet their commitments regarding public deficit and reforms.
These were necessary decisions to ensure financial stability, which must be the European Union's top priority in the short term.
This is not the time, ladies and gentlemen, for certain countries to resort to nationalist maxims and put obstacles in the way.
I have already said it, it is time to bet on Europe.
Spain, ladies and gentlemen, is adopting and implementing in record time the most ambitious reformist agenda in Spanish democracy, which includes a profound labor reform.
Moreover, it is carrying out a financial reform based on total transparency, all of which demonstrates its commitment to fiscal consolidation and meeting deficit targets.

We also welcome the decision to launch a process for greater economic integration through four blocks: a banking union, a fiscal union, a common economic policy framework, and strengthening democracy.
Mr President, the Community, and subsequently the European Union, has always been not only about overcoming crises, but also about emerging stronger from them.
I'm glad that once again we've managed to make it.
Dear colleagues, all our attention is focused on the banks, which we repeatedly hear described as the lifeblood of the social body.
This image is probably accurate, but let's keep in mind that every body is supported by a spine and joints.
Well, the backbone and the joints of that social body we call Europe are precisely its transport networks and its energy infrastructures.
It is essential, as is being said this afternoon here in the Hemicycle, to mobilize private funding and, where appropriate, public funding.
And, moreover, it is an opportunity to promote the issuance of private debt, guaranteed by European institutions, specifically intended for these purposes and open, in addition, to any investor.
Congratulations to the speakers for their work and also to the Commission for its clear support for these projects.

Mr President, dear Commissioner, Minister, as I welcome the new Presidency, I am a veteran activist of the now-defunct Non-Aligned Movement, which was led by your country and which fervently wishes for the territorial integrity of Cyprus in the face of military occupations.

Ladies and gentlemen, we should have taken the opportunity for a more comprehensive reform of the Court, perhaps, but the aspirations of the Commission and of my colleague, the rapporteur, are very positive and should be supported with the unanimity that it received in our Committee.
The agility and proper functioning of the Court are essential, which I question with the new jurisdiction's delayed patent proceedings today.
Congratulations to the speaker, go ahead with the reform of the Court.

Mr President, Commissioner Reding, my country has experienced too many setbacks since the Popular Party came to power, with repeated and continuous attempts to roll back established rights, such as silencing those who speak out, including consumer organizations.
The threat to Facua, which tramples on, among others, Articles 16 and 17 of the Spanish Constitution, by the Ministry of Ms. Mato, is a dangerous attack.

Not only to freedom of expression and opinion, but also to the right to a high level of consumer protection, which are basic principles of democracy and enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.
I therefore call for rectification by the government of Mr Rajoy in the face of the outrage of outlawing Facua and I appeal to the Commission to guarantee the protection of the
defend the rights of Spanish consumers and act against the reduction of rights and the functions of consumer associations that the current Spanish government intends to impose.
Madam President, Commissioner, I would first of all like to highlight the excellent work done by Mrs McAvan, the rapporteur, and also by the other shadow rapporteurs, in reaching this agreement.
This first reading agreement was very important, as it brought into force the regulation that we had approved in 2010 and it was necessary to make some adjustments to it.
Not because it was bad legislation, the legislation was very good, but, as has been said, recent events occurred that are well known and demonstrated that there was a certain
A gap that needed to be corrected so that it would not happen again, and specific points of vigilance and security of the medicines once marketed had to be reinforced.
Therefore, from now on, as stated, holders of a marketing authorization for a medicinal product who do not renew, withdraw or request withdrawal or suspend the authorization will have
It is the obligation to declare the real reasons and motives that have led to this withdrawal or suspension of authorization of a medicinal product.
This is a major achievement in the name of transparency and will prevent the marketing authorization holder from attempting to hide the true reasons for their decision.
Furthermore, in the event that any of these actions is carried out in a third country, all countries, all affected Member States, where this medicinal product is marketed must be informed.
Everything will improve transparency and safety, without overburdening the European Medicines Agency and the national agencies too much.

The second important change that has been achieved is that all authorized products that are subject to a post-authorization safety study are automatically included in a list of products subject to this monitoring.
Lastly, we must not forget that pharmacovigilance plays a fundamental role, and that is why this plenary must approve this proposal.
Mr President, the agreement reached by Parliament and the Council reflects what the Member States involved unanimously approved in the IMO.

We would be faced with the paradox of wanting to solve an environmental problem in some EU countries by creating a major economic problem in the Mediterranean, which does not have that problem, but does have other types of environmental problems whose costs are not intended to be imposed on the rest of the countries.

Mr President, I want to thank once again all those who have made this Directive a reality, the Secretariat, the Commissioner, the rapporteur, all those I have forgotten to mention and all my fellow Members who have stood by us.

I want to say to the victims, all of them, absolutely all of them, without distinction, that for us they and their families have a face, have a name, are real, and, precisely, we are speaking on their behalf.

Today we will work to ensure that this Directive is not just a dead letter, but that, with the commitment and help of Commissioner Reding, which I have absolutely no doubt about, it is implemented quickly and effectively, which is what we all hope for and expect.
citizen.

I believe that there are different groups of victims who wanted and still want their own Directive, but I will tell you that the Directive we will vote on tomorrow does not forget any victim and, therefore, does not forget them either.
And I am sure that this is a first and important step, which will be followed by many others that will open those doors of justice that have been closed for too long for the victims.
When they ask me in my country what I do in Europe, I can proudly say that I am legislating in favor of the victims.
And that work, personally, deeply honors me and gives me a lot of strength to continue working.

I am sure that with the support and commitment not only of those of us working here in Europe, but also in our countries, we will all manage, including with your support, to rescue the victims from that unjust oblivion.

Mr President, Mr Turmes has done an admirable job because it took the courage of this rapporteur to push through a regulation like this, who has managed to overcome the many and skilfully laid obstacles.
It has been worthwhile because efficiency in the use of energy and its conservation are requirements of any energy policy worthy of the name.

We should welcome important measures such as the requirement for public buildings to be renovated, the imposition of an accumulated energy savings percentage on energy companies, as well as mandatory audits for large private companies.
Now, of what use will be the work of Turmes and the rest of the rapporteurs if it is not accompanied by decisive action from the Member States?
An action that, in turn, must be accompanied by a firm commitment to these objectives by the regions, municipalities, and European citizens.
I am interested in highlighting the participation of the latter.
For now, what is noticeable is a lot of frivolity among the authorities and among citizens.
Don't we see, dear colleagues, in the harsh European winter, people sitting on heated street terraces?
Friend Turness, we must spare no effort to save energy.
We must congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs. Aira García, for the work she has done and rejoice at the agreement reached between Parliament and the Council of Ministers.
It's a shame that the Council isn't joining us tonight.
Mr President, the new quality scheme for agricultural products simplifies the system and streamlines the existing authorisation procedures, and that is good news.

Moreover, it is a good achievement that the obligation to use the Community logo for protected designations of origin and geographical indications has been included, because it allows for improved visibility of European productions.
I also think it is noteworthy that the provisions protecting quality appellations are reinforced in bilateral agreements with third countries and that a legal basis is created for
Defend the European Union logo in those third countries, because I sincerely believe that the protection of European products in third countries must be an unrenounceable objective.

It is a shame that this package has been somewhat watered down during the negotiation and it is a shame, I say again, that the Council is not here to listen to it, because the original quality package it proposed

The Commission has somewhat forgotten about the trade standards and supply management by the quality designations of origin, which have been detached from the agreement and, as I say, have left it somewhat empty.
I think we must regret the stubbornness that the Council has shown on these two issues, refusing to listen to Parliament's positions, which are reasonable.
The management of supply by the designations of origin should have been defended and will certainly be defended at the WTO.
