Mr President, the rapporteur's work is very good, but I want to take this opportunity to say here, in this context, that our prose is very confusing, as anyone who looks at European legislation can see.
Let us forget what Pufendorf already taught us: that general laws should be few and their meaning must be understood correctly.
Therefore, those who promulgate it must use all the clarity that is possible.
And Montesquieu always insisted that legal language must be precise and concise.
In other words, we must avoid esoteric jargon, full of neologisms and unjustified linguistic borrowings, because it generates a malicious network where traps lurk and arbitrariness takes hold.
We deal with very complex issues in this Parliament, but it is our obligation to convey them to the public in a comprehensible and accessible way.
It is common for even legal professionals themselves, judges, and lawyers, to become frustrated with our texts.
Good prose, dear colleagues, is the legislator's courtesy and a way of demonstrating their respect for the citizen.
Mr. Deputy, I just spent the little time I had insulting and denigrating from a position of absolute ignorance.
Ignorance. Do you know the Spanish Constitution?

Because what the vice president, Mr. Vidal Cuadras, has said is nothing more or less than applying what is stated in the Spanish Constitution. The rest are singular personal opinions that are completely irrelevant and that I can respect, but which I despise.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there is an old principle that has passed from the legal sphere to the political one, and that is pacta sunt servanda, that is, agreements are meant to be kept.
By this I mean the important measures adopted by the European Council in June to resolve the crisis affecting us.

Since the adoption of these agreements, market pressure has eased and they have welcomed decisions that can break the vicious circle between banks and sovereign debt, as well as plans to move towards a genuine economic and monetary union and the commitment to defend the euro in an irreversible manner.
The European Council, held last week, contains, ladies and gentlemen, undeniable positive aspects. The conclusions on progress towards banking union are satisfactory.
The A27 Agreement is also positive for the launch of the banking supervisor. Finally, it is appropriate that the launch be entrusted to the eurozone's economy ministers.
But it will allow you to make a critical judgment of the biased interpretations that have been made unilaterally of it.

It is not acceptable, ladies and gentlemen, to make private interpretations that could distort the mandate given to the ministers of economy, nor do we approve of presenting as agreements matters that were not even discussed.
It is urgent to move towards a single supervisory mechanism, which must cover all financial entities.
A common deposit guarantee scheme and a crisis resolution mechanism are also needed.
The survival of the euro is linked to the urgent creation of an effective banking union.
Madam President, honourable Members, Commissioner, the advantages of the internal market are indisputable: increased competition, a greater range of products and services.
services, creation of new jobs, more affordable prices for consumers and greater protection, still not enough and we cannot fall into complacency.
However, cultural, linguistic, protectionist and bureaucratic barriers prevent citizens and businesses from fully taking advantage of the benefits of the single market.
A year and a half ago, we celebrated the presentation of the twelve priorities to stimulate growth and strengthen citizens' confidence in the market.
Unfortunately, an agreement has not yet been reached on most of the proposals, as the Commission acknowledged in last week's Communication.

Ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the urgency of the crisis obliges us to be ambitious, to go much further and to reach agreements as soon as possible to boost growth, employment and the confidence of citizens and businesses in the single market.
Mr President, I too want to congratulate the rapporteur and the rest of the colleagues who have worked on this reform so well.

The financial crisis has been exacerbated by the existence of complex and strange negotiable securities that are linked to derivative instruments and negotiations outside of official markets, all with the aim of achieving high returns very quickly.
It is necessary to attract financial operations to a transparent market to ensure the proper formation of prices and competition among tradable products.
But above all, it is essential that the information provided is understandable to investors, who must have full knowledge to give free consent to the risks they are taking on.
Transparency is of no use as a great flash of light if the complexity in the configuration of negotiable products blinds the understanding of citizens.
Mr President, I like Mrs Thyssen's report because I believe that anything that strengthens the role and authority of this Parliament in political debate is moving in the right direction.
All too often we hear accusations against European institutions for their poor democratic quality.
This is a flippant statement, and this is not the occasion to enter into this debate.

Yes, to emphasize that this Parliament has the same legitimacy as any national parliament and is likely, in fact, to be governed by more transparent rules than some, and also allows its members greater freedom.
That is why all economic measures must pass through the filter that this Parliament represents before their final approval and later when examining their execution and results.
the group of experts appointed to verify in the States compliance with the conditions imposed by the Community authorities and the representatives of the Member States
The stability mechanisms must appear in this House so that we Members of Parliament can have access to comprehensive and first-hand information.
Mr. President, 5.3% of the working population works in the automotive sector.
The figures speak for themselves, processed.
The decline in sales in the European market, combined with business strategy, generally leads to outsourcing and restructuring of companies.
There is an overcapacity crisis currently affecting ten assembly plants and potentially one hundred thousand workers.
Unfortunately, there are few cases of restructuring with a long-term vision; a short-term vision generally prevails, in which the main element is to gain competitiveness through labor adjustments.

I must say that on the same day that Ford announced the suspension of the GEN plant, the Valencia Ford company was informed that its production was going to be moved to Germany, in the same corporate announcement.

Therefore, for this reason, we believe that it is a general problem for Europe, we believe that the creation of a legal framework at the European level that anticipates changes and underlines the importance of social dialogue is essential.
Social dialogue is essential.
Mr President, we are debating four reports today that represent a revitalisation of our common security and defence policy.
It is a clear sign of the conviction that our security and defense have a clear European dimension, in the face of minority and Eurosceptic sectors that also prevail in this Chamber.
The report by Mr Danjan, whom I would like to thank for his spirit of consensus-seeking during its preparation, contains important contributions from the Socialist Group.
among others, references to effective multilateralism, the principle of the responsibility to protect, or the concept of human security.
And we would like to see these aspects included in the possible revision of the European defense strategy.
We have also pointed out that a strong common security and defense policy is also in the interest of our transatlantic alliance.
I must highlight another challenge that is taking on significant dimensions for our global security.
It is about cybersecurity and cyber defence, a report that we also discussed today and whose suggestions we hope will be included in the new European cybersecurity strategy.
In a context of severe economic and financial crisis, in which the member states are being forced to cut their defense budgets, it is when European projects are most necessary.
That is why it is more important than ever to reinforce the role of the European Defence Agency, which is being strongly contested today.
I conclude by stating that we can relaunch European security and defense, and do so with the project of former President von der Leyen for the December 2013 Council.
Thank you very much to the four speakers.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, once again the defence of the general interests upheld by the Commission and Parliament clashes with national egoisms entrenched in the Council.
Given the prior acceptance of the legitimacy of both positions, it is inexcusable not to reach a balance.
The relevance of the next financial framework is unquestionable.
The Spanish delegation of the EPP and I, on its behalf, reiterate that the Presidency's proposal is, in our opinion, unacceptable.
A cut of 75 million euros on the already inevitably meager proposal of the European Commission is sterile and useless.
And not only that, the new direct cut to agricultural and cohesion policies means crossing the red line that Spain indicated from the beginning of the negotiations.
Ladies and gentlemen, it is no longer time to argue about a supposed dichotomy between austerity and growth.
Some of us are making proven efforts and sacrifices for deficit correction.
But Spain, like so many other countries, needs to grow, increase economic activity, and create jobs.
And with this budget, you get nowhere; rather, the budget is a lifeline.
Ladies and gentlemen, it is not possible to achieve more Europe with much fewer resources, and especially not if what we have is distributed unfairly.

If that is the case, Spain will oppose a financial framework for the European Union that will simply mean the disappearance of growth opportunities and, above all, any vestige of solidarity, and this is precisely the direction the European Council is taking.
Fortunately, this is not the path indicated by the Commission, who should be thanked for their efforts in pointing out a different route.

And at this point, in the need for Union, in the need for shared efforts, I want to thank Mr. Barroso for making a strong statement the other day in Cádiz interpreting the Treaties for a supposed secessionist within the Union.

He made it clear, unequivocally, as the guardian of the Treaties, that if a part of a Member State separates as an independent state, it becomes considered a third country and, therefore, the declarations and effects of the Treaty itself will not affect it.

I hope, Mr. Vice President, in the absence of the President, that this can be taken into account and that this safe and consistent doctrine of the Commission can continue to remain alive for the benefit of all.
